description:
Good food, though it is pricey. I had the chicken donburi, unagi nigiri, and blue fin tuna nigiri.

the donburi was filling and tasty. Not greasy, good ratio of vegetables, egg, and chicken. $16

The tuna was on their specials wall, it was very tasty. $10 is a little more than I would expect, but who wants bargain sushi anyway?

The unagi was quite special. One of the tastier unagi pieces I've had with good sauce, good oil and sweetness in the meat. $6.50 made perfect sense.

Service was fine and the place was not busy for lunch.
author: Wolf R.

description:
The food we had here was nothing to complain or rave about. The service was great. The seating arrangement was very cramped.  The sushi and donburi were tasty and had no problems, but there seems to be a mismatch between the food and price. I think for the price the sushi should be a bit more amazing or at least bigger portions than this. Practically every roll comes with avocado, too, which to me is a indication of average, not higher end, sushi. 

$65 for two to have a very light meal seems to be a bit high, but perhaps this is due to the exorbitant price the restaurant probably pays for rent.
author: Maya G.

description:
My wife & ordered takeout from Akiko's based on the Yelp reviews. Huge disappointment! 

First of all, when I went in to pick up the food both of the employees (chef and waitress) were speaking Chinese. This is not a Japanese-run restaurant, it's Chinese-run. (Full disclaimer: I lived in China for over a year, speak Chinese and my wife is Chinese-American. I love both Chinese and Japanese food, but the two cuisines are very different.) Not an auspicious sign. 

Then when I got home (2-block walk) and we tried to eat the food it was almost inedible. The Donburi was cold (not even tepid!) so we had to microwave it, and the rice, eel and 'salad' (apparently Safeway mixed greens) were kind of jumbled together in a non-leak-proof cardboard container. The portions were tiny - a dollop of rice and 7 or 8  small slices of eel. (Yeah, I know - "The food was terrible... and the portions were so small!") 

The combination roll was also inedible - one of the worst rolls I've ever had. The only thing that was edible was the sunomono, which is pretty hard to get wrong. 

All in all, very disappointing. We forced it down because we were hungry, and I hope we don't pay for it in the night. If you want good Japanese food then go somewhere else.
author: David S.

description: This is a tiny sushi bar with fresh seafood.  Our sever was very nice and food was out quickly. Being from the Midwest we don't have the same quality sashimi as on the coast and this sushi bar did not disappoint.
author: Heather H.

description:
Came here for lunch because Akiko's Restaurant said our wait would be 2(?!) hours... No, thanks. 

First off, this place is TINY. Thankfully, we came around 12:30pm and it was empty. I can't imagine having to wait for a seat during their busy times. 

Second, the menu is quite standard. We ordered the Cherry Blossom Roll, Scallop Special Roll, a handful of nigiri, and a few basic rolls. They were okay... Nothing memorable. The rolls aren't lux or unique here, but good for a sushi fix. Decent presentation of maki and nigiri. 

Not bad for an average lunch in the city. I can imagine it as an option for a quick work lunch, perhaps. For what we got, though, the food is definitely overpriced and we won't be back. There are literally dozens of Japanese places around the area.
author: Kathy Z.

description: Good sushi. Fast and friendly service. Small dining area. Reservation recommended via yelp. Convenient location.
author: Andrew P.

description:
VERY INTIMATE. 

If the service wasn't decent, I would've given this place 2 stars. The food was okay, the sushi was very sketchy. It did not taste too fresh and was almost warm....WARM. Gyoza was good. Tea was good. That's about it. It has SO much potential to be such a cute datey place because of how small and intimate it is. But I would not want to be disgusted by my food if I went on a date here.  definitely not worth the $30 of food I ate. Overpriced for under quality.
author: Tilly D.

description: It looks like locals and regulars like to eat here. It's a very tiny restaurant and looks like there are times there would be a wait to be seated due to the signboard on the front door. I was walking to class when i felt the craving of stopping by to get some omikase. It was delicious and fresh. The price was average. Servings a little small, but not surprised as its in San Francisco, very near Union Square.
author: Beatrice T.

description:
This is a very tiny place so definitely don't bring strollers in here. 

I ordered their dynamite roll it seems it's the most popular one they have. I ordered take out through the app. My food was ready in a timely manner. The lady also gave me some cabbage salad in the side. The roll itself was delicious but it was very tiny for the price.
author: Rubab M.

description: Very friendly and amazing sushi! Small and quaint! Just what you need in a big city! The miso soup is amazing!
author: Brett M.

description:
It is very cute place. 
The food is wonderful! The list of sake is amazing!!
I would recommended to call to book a place.
author: Ekaterina N.

description: Just stumbled upon this place.  Good sushi good service ..like 4 tables and a bar with 4 stools. If you are looking for a classic hole-in-the-wall sushi bar this is a great choice.
author: Curt P.

description:
Small excellent sushi bar with most everything one would want. Friendly and fast service with fresh sushi. 
Just a block up from Post street.  I enjoyed a wonderful lunch here and have this spot bookmarked.
author: Bruce B.

description: This little hole in the wall of a restaurant is the biggest San Francisco rip off ever!  Stay away!!  We where charged for food we didn't even know we ordered...$39.00 for "sea urchin" that we didn't ask for.  The sushi rolls are very small.  Service was bad.  Overall this place is a waist of time and money.  Plenty of other sushi restaurants out there to choose from.
author: Andrew D.

description:
Had the omakase. It was underwhelming. Nothing interesting, no uni or toro, both of which were on the specials menu. Shrimp head was not deep fried.  Butterfish / escolar and the usual. Everything came at once on a boat. Would have been much better off just ordering off the menu. Not a good value in comparison. 

They were nice and the food was good but with so many sushi places in town I won't go out of my way to go back.
author: Andrew B.

description:
Was looking for a quick fix for a sushi craving while traveling in San fransisco. Did some googling of a near by place and akiko had decent reviews. 

I'd like to start by saying the service was definitely a 5 star. The women who was working was very accommodating for our group of seven people in a very small place. She pushed tables together and even gave us complementary edamame. She provided us with good recommendations and was very helpful to my mom who had a gluten allergy to alter any of the rolls for her. 

We ordered a few of the specialty rolls. They were very tasty but not a bang for your buck. The sushi was pretty expensive and the rolls were very small. When we got our bill we were shocked with how over priced everything was. 

With the amount of sushi restaurants in the area you can definitely fine something more reasonably priced that will pack your rolls full of fish
author: Robin P.

description: So, I liked the fish and the preparation (even if the total bill was a bit too high). But the place is cramped and service while courteous is definitely understaffed and slow. So for food it would be more of a 4 but the total experience leans towards a 3.
author: Stefano Z.

description:
Super tiny sushi bar located in Downtown SF. My friend and I made reservations for 8:30 and had to wait a little to be seated since the restaurant is super tiny. There wasn't really a waiting area, so we sat in the hallway in the complex attached to the restaurant while waiting to be seated. 

Our table was pretty small right at the door. It was a good size for 2 people. We ordered miso soup, which was really good. We also got a Himachi salad, which was nice and crispy. My friend ordered the Yellowtail Special and I ordered the Salmon Special. Both rolls were decent, I've had better here in SoCal, but I still enjoyed my time here. I loved the ambiance and just being in the city!
author: Cathy M.

description: Wow! Shocked this place doesn't have five stars. Definitely some of the best sushi I've ever had!
author: Alex A.

description: Place was very small. Service was good. Food was good but on the pricier side. Water was not free, either sparkling water or $2.25 for a bottled water (arrowhead)
author: Anita S.

description:
Very friendly staff
Great sushi 
The chef behind the bar making the sushi is the nicest guy ever plus have 17 years doing it there he said 
It's a really small place, like really!!! 4-5 tables at the most and won't fit more than 18 people in there but it's very cozy and the food is great
Service is fast
Miso soup is delicious 
I'll come back on my next visit to SF
author: Mariana C.

description: It reminded me of little sushi spots in Japan. The Tuna Tar Tar was delicious and the rolls were tasty! It's small but let let it fool you. The waitress was so busy taking care of everyone but there was never a lack in service. We were lucky that it was just across the street from the hotel we were staying at.
author: Abel G.

description:
Very very VERY ...did i say very? average sushi bar.  Ordered the 12 nigiri, it was decent, and i do have to give them credit for serving me the BEST mackerel I've ever had.  I generally hate mackerel wit a passion but the quality on this baby was finer than fine wine.  Everything else was just average.  One thing to avoid....tuna sashimi, 15 bucks for something that was definitely not worth it.   

Would I come again? probably not.  Especially since Elephant sushi is down the street.
author: Vince L.

description:
Small family owned place with good food and great service.
They have only 5 tables and some bar seats, so consider waiting for at list 15 minuets if you are in a group of 4.
author: Raz G.

description: Sat at the bar and talked to the sushi chef, he's hilarious. Ordered oyster of the day, sashimi combo, sumo roll, akiko roll and beef udon. The only disappointing part was that we couldn't eat more. All is good. No I'm not related to this restaurant. It's legit good.
author: Mike T.

description:
This place was horrible! Walked in and sat down with my family. My mom ordered a miso soup to warm up and didn't receive it until 30 minutes later, longer than tables that came after us. The sushi took 30+ minutes (for something as simple as a cucumber roll) and everyone around us was served mush faster for things that took longer to cook (they came after us). The food was HORRIBLE and the service was WORSE. The restaurant was TINY! Beware that there is a huge chance they won't have space for you and if they do you will be UNCOMFORTABLE.

Additionally, the food is a joke! For example, a spicy tuna roll is a raw piece of tuna with a little spicy mayo, avocado, and cucumber. While I understand hat restaurants make tuna dishes differently, in all my life I have always had this particular dish with the tuna and spicy mayo mixed together. Moreover, the sushi in its own standing failed. The chef did not put any spicy mayo even though it's a vital part of the recipe. 

Our total for everything was $150 for food that was not filling, took an extremely long time and tasted less than average. Additionally, the waitress (who gave us terrible service) added her own tip to our total. 

To summarize: the space is tiny and cramped; the food will take too long, be in small portions, taste underwhelming and bad, and is overpriced; the service is the worst I've ever had and probably the worst you'll have too. 

Beware, I would never go back again-not even if I was paid a million dollars!
author: Megan H.

description: Service was good just the reason why I'm giving it two stars is that they noticed we weren't from here so they gave us smaller portion of the Lion King compared to other plates we were seeing. The place itself is small (like three tables and a small bar counter top type of place). Parking wise, there is a parking garage right next to it but besides that street parking where you pay. The edamame and miso soup we ordered was delicious. The edamame has salt on it and tasted good. The miso soup had a rich flavor and it is on the better side than other places we have tried.
author: Janet B.

description: The quality is very unstable. Fit day we went there, the food (sushi) was amazing. We went there the second day and found out the sushi was almost 1/3 smaller than yesterday. I recommended the sushi with quail eggs, btw.
author: Minzhi Y.

description: The fish was fresh and the staff was friendly. But the rolls weren't particularly well made and were constantly on the verge of falling apart. Not bad but not great.
author: Brian B.

description: We had a California roll, spicy tuna hand rolls, albacore carpaccio and both chicken & beef teriyakis. Everything was excellent, husband said the tuna hand roll melted in his mouth. The Teriyaki sauce was light and delicious with perfectly cooked meat & veggies. Service was excellent as well! Great place all the way around!
author: Donell M.

description: Bravo to phenomenally fresh and great tasting sushi! Do yourself a favor and make time for this hidden gem.
author: Greg W.

description:
I had toro, yellow tail, tuna, and a few other pieces of sushi. I thought the food was very fresh.

I would go back. It is a very small restaurant so seating is very limited. Other than that I would go back.
author: Pat V.

description:
little hole in the wall... so freaking good....
did not expect this too be so good....
author: Micheal R.

description: great neighborhood spot. small space with good food. unagi donburi, sf maki roll, escollar nigiri sushi. done and done.  if you're not all there when your name or reservation is called - next. get in, get out. they won't rush you but there's only a few tables and a 4 seat sushi counter with hungry people waiting outside.
author: A D.

description:
Inexpensive relatively, long wait, but mostly worth it. 

Let me tell you, there is something special about their Cucumber Sunomono here.  It is Delicious.  

Overall, 4 stars.  Service was definitely lacking a bit, and also, we were supposed to be next on the wait list, and the lady put someone ahead of us which added 20 minutes to our wait.  I will be back when I am in the SF Area, if they are not busy as the food was worth the wait.
author: Keaton G.

description: Beware of this place.  They are totally shady. They will offer you a special. Make sure you ask for the price because they will charge you 3x the price of anything else on the menu. They pulled this on myself and at least 3 other customers while I was there. I believe this is actually illegal?
author: neil h.

description:
This place was not bad, we ordered two rolls (double star and rainbow), an order of unagi sashimi and a chicken udon. I did find it more expensive than the other sushi places we visited on our trip. I would have liked to try more variety as other people's pictures on this site look really good, maybe next time. 

The restaurant is super small that can only fit 16 people max (including bar seats).
author: Tony T.

description: This was a find after a long day of shopping in SF! Loved the food, it was fantastic! Sushi was excellent. Small quaint little restaurant. I would definitely visit again !
author: Kris T.

description: This quaint spot is a treasure of delicious sushi. The tuna belly & hamachi were perfect!
author: Missy R.

description:
Came here on a whim with my buddy, and had a great experience.  The roll menu looked too standard so we ordered the Tekka Don and Sake Don. 

Both were amazing.  Would come back for sure.
author: Craig V.

description: Whoa! This place is so good! I always order a mixed greens salad to start and this one is the most gourmet starter salad I've ever eaten! Next I had the escolar special- so fresh and it didn't have any sauces on it which I like- you can taste the fish more. Also order the special of the day- fatty tuna on top with shrimp and avo inside. So rich and delicious!
author: Alli B.

description: Dropped by unplanned, came in with low expectations but was pleasantly surprised. Service was great, received my food very fast (even for sushi). The dragon and rainbow rolls were right on cue. Give you the entire tea pot so you don't have to hassle them for a refill. Very cozy spot so don't plan on a party larger than four.
author: Max N.

description: The best toro I have ever had. The sumo roll was my favorite, but every roll was amazing. The fish was so fresh. I went here last nite and literally can't stop thinking about it. I might try to go again tonite.
author: Sam A.

description: Great place, you could live on fresh fish and ramen like this. Not the cheapest but I think it's worth it. Cosy but nice. I get lunch and never disappoints. Sushi and Gyoza were my regulars. Enjoyed.
author: Ryan S.

description:
Overall, I enjoyed Akiko's. Not mindblowing sushi, but definitely does the job :) The venue is TINY (think 4 tables and 5 bar seats) with 1 server manning the restaurant so be prepared to wait.

We got:
Lizzy roll: yummy conventional salmon / avocado roll with small slivers of lemon on top
Some butterfish roll: Don't remember the name, but was quite good!
Chicken udon: The broth was pleasantly homey and not MSG/soy sauce laden like other udons I've tried before. The chicken was good quality and tender, and the overall portion was quite large. My only gripe was that the noodles didn't taste homemade, but small detail.
author: Claudia C.

description:
Nice little place. Did a Google Search for Seafood near me at 11:30 am, a few options cropped up, but it turned out I was only 30 feet away from their door! The restaurant had literally just opened but most tables were already occupied. A good sign!

I had five very nice and generously sized slices of hamachi sashimi and two hand rolls, one off menu too, which was great. 

Highly recommend giving this place a try. It's tiny inside, so a larger group won't work, but great by yourself, as a couple or a party of four.
author: John R.

description: This place was perfect for us. We were not looking for a hip busy place. We were looking for a good neighborhood. Sushi spot and this was it. The restaurant has 4 tables and is less then 800 sq ft. It seats a max 12 people. The food is great and fairly priced. We will be back here every time we visit San Fran.
author: Stephen P.

description: Such an incredible place! Very small joint- attend with a small party or you'll have to wait. The entire restaurant seas only about 13 guests. However, the food was delicious and moderately priced for being in the city! The sweetest waitress ever served us and she was incredible accommodating! Would return.
author: Lindsay W.

description: Can't recommend this place.  We were craving sushi. But the sushi didn't taste very fresh.  Had kind of dry rubbery texture.  The hot sake was good.
author: Irvin S.

description:
Had the combinations fried rice twice. The cook really knows what their doing. Food tasted even better the next time.

Highly recommend
author: Kweku K.

description:
Worst sushi restaurant Ive ever been. 
1.quality of fish is pretty bad. 2.service was bad.
very overpriced.very disappointed.
author: Judy S.

description:
Food: bad. Fishy and hard, cold rice. Menu is predominantly roll heavy which should have been a warning sign. 

Service: horrible. Waitress barely spoke English and staff blathered loudly in Cantonese (which I understand). Hard upsell on the specials. Said they didn't accept AMEX and tossed my card back on the table. Which clanks because it's metal. 

Ambiance: how this place passed fire code I don't know. Seats near the door are constantly body checked by people going in and out. 

I have regratz
author: Ryan K.

description:
We went here to grab a quick bite before a concert at Nob Hill Masonic. The restaurant is tiny, like a converted coat check room (but tastefully decorated), and it's all downhill from the Masonic so it's a steep climb to get back! 

Lots to choose from on the menu, the waitress was very knowledgeable about gluten free options, and when we explained we were in a hurry, she helped us select dishes that could be turned around quickly. 

But besides being fast, our sushi was beautiful and delicious! I wish it was closer to home because I definitely would come back!
author: Marc M.

description:
This place has the best tasting salmon! I've been to many sushi bars and their sushi is so fresh and authentic. 

I was a bit caught off guard to the size of the area. There's literally 4-5 small tables and a 3 person bar. Luckily, it was just my boyfriend and I so we got to sit ASAP. Not really ideal for big groups because of the space.
author: Jasmine C.

description: An amazing night in town for sushi! It has a home-like environment, but a first class destination for incredible sushi. Only problem is the small space... but you go there for the experience. Don't expect to just walk in and get a table, though I got lucky and that very thing happened. Enjoy the incredible food and wonderful window view of the city.
author: Ellizar M.

description: Just like any Sushi bar in Japan, this place is small and quaint. Excellent place to have meet with friends, family or business associates! They have unique and tasty sushi rolls and their fish is always fresh. Definitely a hidden gem in SF!
author: Carmen H.

description:
Top sushi bar in SF. Great service and super food.
I'll definitely raccomand this lovely place
author: Anna N.

description: Food was absolutely subpar. The fish was mediocre. There is a complete lack of authenticity. Based off the reviews I had very high hopes. Small does not equal authentic, you've been warned.
author: Matt H.

description: I'm from Chicago so all the sushi is probably just better in SF, but I am still thinking about this place days after my trip. I was staying at the JW Marriott across the street and had time for a quick lunch before my meeting started so I popped in for a few rolls. The place is definitely small but the service was speedy and the quality was fresh and fantastic. I loved the salmon nigiri, and some fancy roll with scallop and salmon. Bonus points for the perfectly ice-cold Diet Coke!
author: Neena P.

description: Made reservations for 7:30. Showed up at 7:30. They told us it would be at least half an hour wait. I said "we have reservations for 730". They said something along the lines of that I had made the reservations too recently. In my book a reservation is a reservation. Thumbs down.
author: Dan D.

description: The food isn't bad and I've been there a few times. I stopped after one incident. I went on a crowded night and was told to put my name on a waiting list on a board outside the entrance. After about 20 minutes, someone left. I waited outside for them to call my name. Someone walked by and in and got seated without having to wait, taking the place that the other person had been sitting. No one ever checked the waiting list to see if someone, me, had put his name down and was waiting. I went in complained and left. Never been back. They're not good enough to risk that happening again. If you're going to have a waiting list for diners but you don't check it, why would I bother?
author: T F.

description:
Super tiny, neat spot in downtown.

Ordered tuna poke after it was enthusiastically recommended by the server. 
The tuna had a strong fish flavor which meant it was not fresh.
I did not eat it, when asked explained I did not find it fresh and was rewarded with indignation. 
It was not removed from the bill. 

My partner order the teriyaki chicken which he liked. 

Maybe the sushi is better.
author: Nancy G.

description: So good. Relatively inexpensive for sushi in SF. Impeccably fresh fish and s very talented sushi chef. This is a tiny place but friendly and frequented by Japanese people. The unagi hand roll was outstanding.
author: Linda G.

description:
I must say, I'm quite surprised by the reviews. There aren't that many places in San Francisco where you can consistently get good sashimi - and Akiko's on Mason (no relation with the place with the same name on Bush) is easily on top of that list. I normally end up eating the sashimi combo which includes their delicious butterfish. On the cooked menu, the eggplant is pretty good. 

If you want good sashimi in San Francisco, this is the place.
author: Dilip P.

description: Delightful little sushi place that my partner and I found after having had a bad experience at another restaurant nearby. The intimacy of the place made it quite the romantic spot, and we really enjoyed the food and the service, and the staff were very patient, even though we turned up an hour before closing. If you're in the area, I can certainly recommend this as a great place to visit.
author: Andy  B.

description: The food is amazing. The green salad, miso soup, chicken udon, teriyaki chicken and rice. We both enjoyed ourselves here! The reason it doesn't get 5 stars is that it was hot as Hades in there and it is EXTREMELY small. 4 bar stools and 4 tables...
author: Zandra P.

description:
Came here late Wednesday night.  We did wait about 10 min for a table because there is only 4 tables, each seating 3 people to 5 people. Plus a sushi bar that sits about 2  people comfortably-3 elbow to elbow.  Service was very rushed but food was good! 

Sashimi was very good - cold, fresh and nice thick slices. 
Rolls were alright - nothing out of the ordinary.  So I'd come back for sashimi!
author: Erika G.

description: We have been coming here for years, I think it's one of the best sushi restaurants in SF... Great service and excellent food! Love it!
author: Phil L.

description: I came here on a Friday around 6:30pm as a walkin. It was a small space, but we didn't have to wait, which was nice. I tried three of the rolls, and the assorted nigiri. The fish was really fresh, and the rolls were great. I especially liked the disco roll. A bit pricey, but I would come back again!
author: Cynthia M.

description:
This is the smaller sibling of another location I guess. And it most definitely is quite small, three or four tables and a bar. We walked in early without reservations and were sat at the bar.

There was just one dude rolling everything right in front of us and he was really cool to watch. Just him making sure he chose the right piece of fish to cut from each time was  so engaging it was almost hard to think about anything else. There was a kitchen in the back where the soups and other dishes were being prepared.

Ma girl got the udon noodles, which I thought were really awesome. She later informed me that udon noodles are actually hard to screw up. But I personally don't think that had much to do with how good those noods were. We shared that bowl and had like 6 rolls otherwise. I don't think I've ever had a spicy tuna or salmon roll made as intricately as this. The chef made the simple taste truly fantastic. Couple in the high quality of fish they were serving, and it was lights out.

Other notable things from this venture were the lack of table space, and the intricacy of their wasabi delivery. When we were in there literally every seat was taken and the space became quite cramped. As homegirl and I definitely don't take our orders lightly. We easily knock out like 6-8 rolls each time we grab sushi. So we couldn't support all of our rolls with the table space available, we had to consolidate different rolls onto one plate, probably wouldn't have been a deal if we made reservations and just got a normal table. Also the wasabi came out with a special little leaf design on it and as simple as that was NO other sushi spot I've been to regardless of price has done this. I love when places pay special attention to little details like this, makes them all the more memorable.
author: Jim B.

description: The sashimi is fine - fresh, typical pricing - but what I want to talk about is the seafood udon.  The broth had a very light and fresh seafood flavor, the noodles were delectably chewy.  It came with a good variety of seafood, though the fish became overcooked in the hot soup.  Oh well, it happens.  Also, the bowl was huge.  For about $15, I was full and nice and toasty after my meal.
author: Beatrice W.

description: Mmm... hope you like bugs because there was atleast 5 in my soup. Then they tried to have us pay for the soup.
author: JR C.

description:
Came here yesterday with some friends for dinner. It's a very small place - just 4 tables and 2 seats at the sushi bar. The menu is also quite limited

I ordered a eel donburi and there were more veggies in it than eel. Overall it was okay, but I wouldn't recommend coming here if you're with a large group or if you want to eat more than just sushi rolls.
author: Emily P.

description: This place is fantastic! Tiny but awesome.  My friend and I had the 49er roll and the swamp roll, miso and edamame.  We will definitely come back again.
author: Leigh H.

description:
Good sushi bar. While the place is small and the staff is not Japanese, the sushi is very fresh. Had the sashimi combo and the value is average. 10 pcs for 17.50, each pc is about the size of my thumb. Not a lot of fancy selection. The usual tuna and salmon. A big plus for them is the wasabi. It is the type that adds flavor without shooting up your nose.  Spread it on the fish, font put it into the soy sauce. They gave a lot of ginger and I like that. The salad and soup that accompanied the entree is average. Want fresh sushi at average price, come here.

Oh. They have regulars coming back and the waitress remembers them, where they sat, what the ordered. Impressive.
author: Khiang S.

description: Love this sushi bar! Hidden gem in San Francisco, should definably try it. I love this tiny restaurant, their service  including the food there, fresh n tasty.
author: Jason C.

description: The brown garlic soy sauce on the "Sumo roll" is amazing. One of my favorite sushi experiences of all tome
author: Alex R.

description: The quality and preparation of sushi at Akiko's is excellent. Service is genuine and friendly. The space is small and often only one server, so be patient and savor it. I really like the seafood salad. My only complaint is that the serving sizes are quite  small and price tags quite large.
author: Helen P.

description:
There are not a ton of great lunch options near Union Square but a colleague of mine found Akiko's.  It's right around the block from my work so makes it super easy.

The spot is tiny so I'd suggest getting there right when it opens.  I got the chef's selection and it was pretty good.  The spicy tuna had a nice kick to it.
author: Blake B.

description: It had great choice of elegantly designed sushi,,,everything was fresh,,,tiny place but comfortable,,,
author: Coco S.

description: So my standard for sushi is pretty high. I enjoy trying different sushi places even knowing I can be allergic. Hahaha. That's how much I love sushi. Having that said, this place is ok. The sashimi was not bad. It did not have any fishy flavor and was enjoyable to eat. Not the best I've had. The Lizzy Roll was nothing amazing. But for $9, it was worth it. The Lion King Roll...sucked! Nothing like what u think it would be. I didn't get it baked in foil with toasted mayo on top. It was baked but with a weird flavored sauce . Not worth $15 bucks!!!! I would rather have gone to Domo or Amami and their lion king is ten times better and cheaper! Another sushi place to try but will not return. I, however, will still try the one on Bush since it looks like it was rated higher by fellow yelpers.
author: Cheryl V.

description: Yay! My husband and i finally made it here, after always walking by it on our way home. Usually there is always a line, however we just happened to stumble upon here on a rare earlier seating of the night and scored a seat right away. The fish here is ok, as I am not sure what the rave reviews are over. Service is good. The only drawback is the lack of space as the restaurant is cramped. We can now say that we've been here, and maybe we'll be back.
author: Tracy C.

description: I gave them 3 chances, each time for take out. The sushi has been fresh and good each time. The first time they told me 15 minutes and it took 25. The second time I called it in and is was ready shortly after I arrived. Last night I tried to call multiple times and they did not answer. I went in and ordered just simple sashimi with a 16 minute promise. It took well over half an hour, the waitress was grumpy and the chef just ignored us. I guess the stress just gets to them. That was the last chance.
author: Jeff H.

description: friendly waitress, fast food out, food was good/standard (not bad but nothing that stands out). we ordered the chef's vegetable pick, miso soup, and a veg roll. the place is small though. two tables that fit 4/5, two tables that fit 2, and one sushi bar that fits 3.
author: Eliza C.

description: Thank you Yelp. I was looking for a good sushi place nearby my hotel, and Akiko's name popped up several times. I had Philadelphia and special Salmon rolls afterwards spicy  tuna and salmon, which were super delicious. Great discover.
author: Francesco R.

description:
The space is small, but the rolls are huge in flavor! The BF and I had a philly roll, the lion king roll, the kamakaze roll, and the dragon roll.

All four were delicious - the lion king came baked and it was a nice change from the cold rolls. The kamakaze was spicy but not too hot, with a nice kick at the end. The dragon roll had delicious BBQ eel and avocado on top - YUM. The Philly roll was your standard roll, but the pieces were a bit on the small side.

All in all, it was an excellent dinner and left us both very satisfied. Our waitress was very attentive and patient with us while we made our selections.
author: Marissa F.

description:
Absolutely horrid. Do not come here. If I could give them something lower than one star, I would.

I went here with my sister and friend. Let me start out by saying that the three of us have eaten at numerous sushi bars/restaurants, from low grade but fresh, to air flown directlyfrom Japan. This is not my first rodeo. 

One of my sushi pieces today had a bone in it. I pointed it out to the waitress, and showed her the bone. After she told the chefs, the chefs proceeded to talk about how surprised we were to find bones in our fish - in Cantonese. "They ordered fish, and were surprised to find bones?" What the chefs didn't know was that I actually speak Cantonese, and understood everything they said. Anyone with a 1st grade education could tell you that fish have bones. I can also tell you that it's a chef's job to prep the fish, which includes deboning the fish, especially if the fish is meant for sushi/sashimi purposes. Note: at no point did they offer to replace the piece of sushi with the bone. (My sister later commented to the chefs that we understood them, and they just stood there staring blankly at her, speechless.) 

Next, another piece of my sushi had a sand-y solid piece of "rock" (unknown actual substance) inside the rice. It was so hard my tooth nearly chipped as I bit down, and I had to spit out that piece. Even after spitting out the piece, I had small sand-y pieces of that unknown substance left in my mouth that I had to wash down with soup. 

Come here at your own peril. Be prepared to debone your own sushi, check the rice you are about to bite into, and be prepared to have the chefs talk about you while you are still in the restaurant.
author: Sharon K.

description: This is a teeny tiny place, but the sushi has BIG flavor. Maybe we got lucky. We only had to wait two minutes on a Saturday night to get seated. We enjoyed the Seafood Udon (large fish pieces), the San Francisco roll, Saki Maki, and (highlight) the Double Star roll. We added this place to our "will return" spots.
author: John B.

description:
At A tiny place with four tables and just three seats at the sushi bar, I was expecting to get a little bit of personal attention since I was the only one at the bar. And though it was only 930 on Friday night I got the distinct impression that the chef just wanted to go home. They didn't so much ask if I wanted anything to drink nor offer tea or water. I had to requested only after my food had been served.

The fish wasn't bad, but when you're paying $15 for six small pieces of sushi and for little slices of a perfunctory tuna roll, I expect a little more interest and engagement from the chef and the staff especially as I was one of the few customers you've been able to lure into your establishment.
author: David A R.

description: Very small yet hospital restaurant. Good, smiley service. I had udon, my friend had sushi and we both had a good time. Although small and busy we didn't feel rushed. I'd go again.
author: Mali E.

description: Order the saba.  Its divine.   This little eatery is tiny but full of heart!   Will be back.  Lots.
author: Jonathan b.

description: I was extremely disappointed in my experience here. I wanted an omakase style meal which was reported on yelp but which they do not offer and also was also told no when I asked for a specific cut of tuna, and I waited 10 minutes at least for a drink refill which actually never came: the real problem is that they didn't care at all, no alternative recommendations or help. SO disappointing!!!!!!!
author: Kathy S.

description: I absolutely love this place. It is a complete hole in the wall, and the food they serve is delicious. Reasonably priced, quick service, and excellent sushi. Cannot say it any clearer than that.
author: Ella P.

description: Awesome fresh fish. The chef is great to chat with. He's very happy and friendly guy. Plus the plates are very beautiful and well placed. The place is small but very cozy and the service is fast.
author: Kenshi W.

description:
This tiny sushi bar is a quiet reprieve from the bustling city.  The staff is helpful, hospitable and appropriately attentive. The sushi is fresh and eloquently designed, particularly the 49er's roll.  This SF specific roll features salmon and lemon, most places in the city apply a thin slice of lemon to this roll, at Akiko's Sushi Bar only a thin slice of the lemon's flesh is used.  It's genius. (The last place I went to used the rind and it overwhelmingly muted the salmon.)

Also noteworthy was the tuna tartare starter, it was a perfectly balanced blend of tuna, sesame oil and a hint of garlic.  

Important: This is not the place to go of you're into crunchy, gooey, mayo drizzled sushi rolls.
author: mandeep M.

description:
Interesting place.  It is very tiny.  3 seats at the counter& 2 tables for 4 & 2 tables for 2 in the window. The staff is Chinese, not Japanese.  They were speaking Cantonese to each other.  Must have bought it from the prior Japanese owners.

I just had a unagi donburi and a large bottle of Saporro.  The beer was freshly bottled and cold; can't say that each time I've had it.  The donburi came w/miso & a salad.  Oddly, the unagi was placed on the salad on top of the rice.  There were also some edamame and chopped cucumber included w/the salad.  The unagi tasted ok but seemed a bit undercooked - not raw - to me because it did not seem as firm as I am used to having it served to me.

The bathroom is located in the basement to the apt bldg in which the sushi bar is s located.  You have to access it thru the apt lobby down a narrow stairway.  It's located across from the coin op laundry under the stairway.  THAT's very Chinese.

Should also note that the prices are about 50-60% higher than indicated in the Yelp online menu. The donburi cost me $15 when it's lusted online. for $10 but they do take credit cards.

Can't say whether the Chinese staff affects the authenticity of the food negatively but if you're looking for an out of the way, less touristy place to eat something Japanese while downtown, Akika's may be the place 4 you.
author: Martin C.

description: Was not happy with the service - I sat down, read the menu for 10 mins, ordered, and then the waitress told me that their kitchen is closed so only sushi is available. She should have told me when I sat down. For sushi, the rice is wrong. The sushi fish is very fresh though. I ordered eel roll Caterpillar and the sauce tasted like Chinese pork source - very wired. Also, I realized the chefs are speaking Cantonese, which means they are from south of China or Hong Kong, not Japan.
author: Anya C.

description:
This is what I want when I go out for sushi. I want to feel like I am ordering things that I couldn't get from other places and if i can that is it done in a way that is worth going out for. Everything about the set up of this place and the quality of the food made it worth if for me. 

The place is incredibly small so be prepared to wait for a seat or if you are lucky to be squeezed in next to several people. Once you are finally able to get in you are greeted by an eclectic menu of sushi. We ordered the nigiri and several rolls when we went. 

The sushi was so delicious and fresh and I wanted to come back and try more. The only problem was that I would not want to wait in that line again or have to sit in the cramped building again. It is worth stopping by and trying once but unless you are able to go during non peak hours its hard to recommend it being your only stop. 

For the sushi lovers out there it is a great little spot near union square and should be checked out if you are looking for alternatives to Ryokos.
author: Nick R.

description: Probably some of the best sushi I have had. I have lived in central Cali and so cal and nothing like this place. The sushi is fresh and the ingredients are fresh as well. I had a great experience here because I was greeted as sook as I came into the restaurant and the goodness prepared promptly. I had the dragon roll and the another roll with spicy tuna. Not only is the food really good they make it aesthetically pleasing. I will be coming back here again.
author: Christopher R.

description:
Chanced upon this small restaurant while hanging out with my buddy from Japan. The sushis were high quality. The maki rolls were done just the way they should have been - simple yet sophisticated (no mayo or any of that sort). 

Note:
The place is small, it literally houses less than 25 seats.
author: Lee-Hong L.

description: First time trying Akikos tonight and I am in LOVE! The cozy atmosphere and delicious sushi will have me coming back again and again!
author: Lauren S.

description: Food was decent. Just very very small portions. Order for 2 equals one small serving for 1 person.
author: Guy H.

description: What an amazing experience I had eating here at Akikos. Not only was my food delicious, my waitress was an amazing asset to my dining experience. She took a Polaroid of us as well which melted my heart
author: Brook H.

description: We stumbled across this place by chance. I had never been to such a tiny restaurant! Talk about intimate! Sushi was good and cheap.
author: Karina M.

description: If you ask the sushi chef what his favorite is.....and his says, I don't like sushi...enough said.
author: Fickle O.

description: Outstanding.  Went at 5 pm to beat the rush at this tiny restaurant.  Some of the finest sushi ever.  Two of us split sashimi salad, two rolls and a sashimi platter.  Not cheap, but great value.
author: Cris F.

description: I have eaten sushi all over the world and was surprised by outstanding quality of the fish at this place.  They have an excellent selection and everything we ate was exceptionally fresh.  We had aji, saba, hamachi, baby squid among other nigiri and New Zealand (!?) salmon sashimi that was among the best I have ever tasted.  Silky in texture with abundant fat and deep flavor.  Highly recommended.
author: James T.

description:
We had reservations at Akiko's Restaurant.  We accidentally went here as the two are very close by. I walked in and told them I had a reservation and gave them my name. They went to a little piece of paper and said oh yes, you're right here on our list.... then they sat us at our table.

Never were we told: Oh, you've got the wrong place.   Shame on us for not double checking the address.

With that in mind the Sumo Roll and the 10Pc Sampler were very good for their price point. We were upset that they weren't upfront with us but happy that we did have a decent meal.

This is Cash Only, by the way. They told us that their machines had broken that day, however, many reviewers are reporting that it's always been cash only.  We went to the ATM and got $200 out because we were expecting a very upscale expensive sushi experience. We spent $33 haha.
author: Karen A.

description: Very small place but very cozy. Excellent and very hospitable service. Went there on Sunday and everything we ordered was delicious. You can see a person rolling your sushi right in front of you. Service is very efficient and you can tell that they care about you having a wonderful experience. Can't wait to go back.
author: Jasminka K.

description:
Note: As of 4/20/13 the menu on their website was NOT up-to-date nor were the prices accurate. The current menu is a lot better (more options) than the website menu and the items are about $1-$2 more than advertised on the online menu.

PROS:

-Prices very reasonable.
-Good sushi! Nothing too fancy about this place. This place made me love California rolls though  (typically not a crab fan). 
-Service was good and pretty fast!

CONS:
-The sushi rolls are a bit on the smaller side, but this might actually be an okay thing if you want to order a bunch of different rolls since they're all so cheap.
-It's a small sushi bar. Has 4 tables and 3 seats at the bar. There is seating total for about 15 people. Not good for large groups, as you may not be guaranteed seats.

Verdict? I would probably only come back here to get take-out since the place is so small and casual. I wouldn't come back here for a proper sit down sushi dinner. 

Nevertheless, cheers for cheap sushi!
author: Janaia R.

description:
When my family and I went to this restaurant, the wait was 10 to 15 minutes. We decided to go here because all of the other restaurants didn't look appealing. So after that we were able to get our table.
       When we went to the table, we ordered a donburi, a beef teriyaki, a sashimi, a miso marinated salmon, and a chicken udon. Everything was excellent, and the sashimi was really fresh. Also we ordered some rolls, like the lizzy and dragon rolls. These two rolls were very fresh!! Overall, I thought this restaurant is worth it, and you should give it a try when you are in San Francisco!
author: Matthew D.

description: Definitely a great spot for good sushi. Food is excellent. Prices are a little high considering the other options nearby but the quality of the location certainly warrants it.
author: Ryan P.

description: Very small place, about five tables. No suitable for big groups. Service is good and sushi very fresh. No much creativity going on with their plates and service...just plain sushi.
author: Homar M.

description:
I'm going to be honest, I stumbled here accidentally because I could not get into Ryoko or Sanruku. However, I am glad I did. The other two places had super long lines. This PLACE IS SO CUTE CAUSE ITS SO SMALL. When my boyfriend and I walked into this place and was offered a table (after being rejected by the other two sushi restaurants), our eyes widened and we were amazed at the small size of the restaurant. YOU REALLY HAVE ROOM FOR US? WELL SURE THEY DID. There are 4 tables total in this restaurant and we got one!

We got three rolls total and that might have been too much. I got a dragon roll and then I forgot the other two. I do remember that the rolls were pretty fresh and not bad at all! I will definitely come back again but be cautious since there are only four tables there!
author: Eileen W.

description:
Good fish.

They were out of most things.. including tamago, inari, tamari sauce... And also water apparently, since it never came. Each item required its own trip back to our table to let us know they were out "so sorry".

As a side note, Bel Clift market around the corner sells Tamari. I walked over to buy some after my food arrived and they let me know they couldn't find the Tamari.
author: Jon R.

description:
We were trying to find parking so we could go to Chinatown and looked at Yelp for close Sushi places. We parked, asked a doorman for directions to one we had found and he recommended Akiko's which was right across the street, rather than walking for 10 minutes.

We went at 12p on a Monday, so it was quite busy. It's fairly small, seating maybe 30 people at tables and maybe 10 at the Sushi bar. We waited about 5 minutes while they set us up a table. It took another 5 minutes for a server to come over to us. 

There were a handful of rolls, Nigiri, Sashimi and a few other things to choose from. They were out of Unagi, which we usually get. We ended up getting a Spicy Tuna Roll, a Salmon Roll, Salmon Nigiri, another kinf of Eel Nigiri and Hamachi Kama. 

Overall it was decent sushi but in our opinions not worth what we paid, especially considering they tried to put their own spin on rolls or sauces. It took a long time to get our food and we always have a few go to rolls and pieces we like, and they didn't have any of them.

I'd recommend this place to try if you're open to a limited menu and don't mind spending a little more for the experience and not mind blowing sushi.
author: Vina T.

description: They are great! Great food and excellent service! I am glad to discover this tiny restaurant on Saturday, March 11.   I ordered the butterfish, Hamachi belly, salmon belly, albacore belly sashimi and Hamachi kama. Their sushi was overall pretty fresh and tasty. Server was very quick and professional. I love this place and did not disappoint!
author: Victoria T.

description:
Went here with the hubby for his bday.

We opted to do the Omakase at the sushi bar.  The chef who took care of us was beyond amazing.  We ordered the sake and the chef took it from there.  He prepared some of the best and well thought out sushi I've had.  I am not sure how many items we had, but a few times along the way he asked us how many more dishes we would like so he could time everything out.  We were a bit shocked at the bill (lol), but in the end, it was worth it.

I had been here about 10 years prior and sat at the tables, wasn't too memorable.  This time around, I definitely won't forget!
author: LM F.

description:
After hanging out with LA Yelpers Jenny B, Valerie C and Anthony N in North Beach, I stumbled upon this little sushi joint located on the edge of Union Square. From the outside looking in, the fresh wasabi-colored interior was put together with four tiny tables, a sushi bar, and quite a few attractive diners. I took interest in this place after noticing their window menu that included a 10-piece sushi combination for $11.50. Interestingly this place has a female sushi chef and her presence caught me off guard for not being critically reflective enough about the extent of gender disparities in the restaurant business up to this point.

They didn't have a restroom on premise so instead the server handed me a wet napkin that she prepared over the sink so I could clean my hands. My sushi combination came with hamachi, ebi, sake, two types of tuna and butterfish. It also came with four pieces spicy tuna roll which were buttery with crisp cucumber and green onions wrapped around the tight sushi rice and bright orange tobiko. All the nigiri were decent and fresh with the butterfish really stood out. Without knowing the amount of spicy tuna was already included in the order, I got another Spicy Tuna Temaki ($3.50) which was redundant but the Spicy Unagi Fresh Salmon Temaki ($4) was gigantic and a mouthful of buttery sweetness. The side dish of pickled cabbage was decent.

Service was quick but distanced without a whole lot communication about the division between nigiri and rolls in the sushi combination and the types of fish the chef was going to include. Added to the ambiguity was also a sense of inconvenience without having access to a restroom on the premise. I thought the quality of their nigiri was not ultra fresh 5 stars, but each piece ranged from decent to good. With a 3.3 stars final rating, here's how they fared in each of the categories that are important to my sushi meals:

1.) Quality and freshness: 3.5 stars
2.) Creativity and presentation: 3.5 stars. 
3.) Quantity and substance: 3.5 stars. 
4.) Accessibility and affordability: 4 stars. 
5.) Service and ambiance: 2 stars. 

This place won't be able to compare to the sushi restaurants that has better ambiance and facilities in the Richmond Districts, but with Union Square full of expensive tourist traps, I'd be interested in returning when I'm in the area.
author: Daniel L.

description: I highly recommend this place. They have really good sushi rolls and fresh fish. I have been coming for years and the quality remains excellent. Service is outstanding and the environment is very home like.
author: Michelle C.

description:
Worst Sushi ever. Feel dirty, place isn't clean....
The Chief pass the Sushi with dirty hand. Never come back to this place again!
author: Leslie W.

description:
Fish isn't as fresh as the Bush location. 

Salmon special roll: I thought it was ok. The roll was butchered in all odd shapes but whatever.

Caterpillar: Typical. You can't really go wrong with heating up already made unagi and slapping it together with avocado and rice right?

10 piece sushi lunch: This came with 2 salmon, 1 tai, 2 hamachi, 1 maguro and 6 pieces of spicy tuna. Mmm is my math off? That's more than 10 pieces. Oh well. Salmon was fresh, sweet and a large cut, the tai and maguro were ok but the hamachi was fresh and buttery. Spicy tuna, again, typical. 

Miso: $2? Ripoff.

Side note: They give you a little dish of free pickled cabbage. It's good. Eat it. Oh and this place is TINY. Like super hole in the wall.
author: Beverly T.

description: i always pass by akiko's when i'm on the bus and the other night after i got off work i was craving for sushi, so i yelped to see what places were still open and that were super close by my work. i saw akiko was still open for about 20mins and i know restaurants hate when ppl come super last min, so i called to see if i could order togo and the lady said yes but they were closing in 20min i said "no problem i'm a block away." when i got there the server carmen was super nice and friendly and i was thankful i was able to get my order in. we chatted for a bit while i was waiting for my order. i ordered the hamachi special roll and lion king roll and she said those were the best rolls and that the hamachi is flown in fresh from japan and to be honest i love hamachi and it was BOMB the lion king was hella good too! when i saw the size of the rolls i thought they were a bit small like other people mentioned in the reviews but quality was delish and i will def be going back. oh not to mention the side of pickle cabbage it came with was seriously to DIE for!
author: stacy l.

description:
Anne K and I ended up dropping by here for a bite after one of the last YEE's.

The space is really tiny, but they served pretty good sushi. Their wait staff is on the slower side (read serves like they're exhuasted) and sadly our drinks had to be requested a couple times before they were brought out.

The only real negatives for me were that the chef doesn't hand stuff to you, thus food somtimes sits there for a bit when you could be eating it and it's generally pretty hard to move around if you're at the bar. 

I'd come back and try it again though.
author: Meg T.

description: Small cozy place. Great service. Wonderful suggestions. MISO soup , Lionking , 49er and seaweed salad ALL well seasoned , fresh and a taste explosion. The place probably seats 20 and your best bet is to go early. You could also sit at the bar. Locals frequent often do you know it's the real deal.
author: karen f.

description: We went to this Akikos since the other one (more upscale and a date place) was full and they didn't take walk ins. We lucked out since there were 4 of us and the place I swear has less than 15 seats in total. THe second we sat down we just started seeing other people get rejected since there was no way they would fit. The rolls are good but i wish I went for more sashimi. The people who work here are really nice (sometimes slow) but on the flip side they do not rush you at all.
author: Lily P.

description:
Tasty sushi and fast service. 

The venue is a little small, but that's not their fault-- it's SF!

Try the sumo roll, and the server will always offer up suggestions to your taste.
author: Alli J.

description: Had been here 4 years ago and the sushi is high quality. Space is very limited like 20 seats or so but this is exactly what creates the atmosphere. A bit prizy like everything in SFO but definitely worth the money.
author: Dan C.

description: Stumblef upon this place my first night in SF. Very small (4 tables and about 4 counter tops). Had a miso soup for an appetizer. Was really good! Ordered rock n roll roll, philly roll, kamikaze roll and a disco roll!!
author: Tyler F.

description:
Not fat people friendly.

I went here while I was in San Francisco for a training course. Being fat and lazy, I decided to eat at the closest place I could find from the JW Marriott. Akiko's Sushi Bar was the first place I saw. This place is tiny. There's only 1 sushi chef, 1 server, 1 kitchen staff, 4 tables, and 15 seats. Everyone had to walk sideways to get around. Surprisingly it was very busy. The prices were moderate. I didn't want to eat too much, so I went with the Sushi Combo, which came with Miso Soup & 7 pieces of sushi. I also order Green Tea (which tasted like barley tea) and some sort of spicy tuna roll appetizer. Everything was just decent. Nothing really stood out and nothing was really bad about it. I'm not sure if they have a bathroom either. 

A little about my credentials:

I first got into cooking & food when I was in college. After being rejected by numerous girls and getting zero action, I decided it was time for a change. I needed a new makeover to boost my geeky, engineering image. I applied for a cooking position at a Mediterranean-Italian  Restaurant near my home and learned to cook all sorts of pastas and dishes. I never became a professional chef, but I continue to enjoy & love food. 8 years later and 55 lbs heavier, I am now an engineer that travels all over the world trying new foods and learning about different cultures.
author: Robert S.

description:
The sushi and the chicken teriyaki were amazing! The place is tiny but the atmosphere is cozy an really nice
 We really enjoyed our dinner there. And the welcoming and lovely waitress is a great plus!
author: Gaby V.

description: Good service good food. Fav dish of the night was the catapilar roll. It was done a little different than I an used too, but delish. Sashimi ahi great, but as expected,  had to screw up. Place is small as pointed out in other reviews. Parking is as special as any place in SF. They only take Visa or Mastercard... or cash :).
author: Bill W.

description: My husband and I ate here with our toddler last night. We had a delicious meal with friendly and accommodating service. While there wasn't a high chair, we sat comfortably on the bench seat by the window. The flavors and quality of food are excellent. We had vegetable udon, a cut roll, hand roll and chirashi, along with some miso soup. Very tasty! I wish the udon had a little bit more vegetables in it, but it was very good nonetheless. Get to this place early though, it fills up quickly because it's just a couple of tables.
author: Christa F.

description: My friend and I stopped into Akiko's for sushi on a recent trip to San Francisco.  It was conveniently located across from our hotel and that made it a great choice because our feet were killing us by the end of the trip.  It is a very, very tiny sushi bar, it had maybe 18 seats, and that would be pushing it.  I had called at 6:30pm and they were full, so we walked over at 7:15 pm and sat at the bar right away.  We were clearly between rushes, because as we left the whole place was full again.  The sushi was lovely, very fresh and nice big slices of fish.  We had Mugaro, Butterfish, and a Spider Roll, as well as some other roll I can't remember the name of with Yellowtail.  It was really really tasty!  Highly recommend!
author: Lyssa D.

description: Very rude service.  Will talk about customers in Cantonese assuming you don't understand what they are saying.  Fish was okay but be careful of bones. Apparently, they don't de-bone their fish but expect their customers to find the bones in their mouth. Come here only if you want to be insulted.
author: Linda H.

description:
Very strange.  Only three tables and 2 seats at the bar.  Waitress forgot to bring ordered sake and edamame but remembered to charge for them.  The price of the sake on the menu did not match the charge on my bill - the bill charge was double the menu price.  

3 parties were turned away from an empty available table.

Waitress ate at the table next to us while we were there, then burped loudly without covering her mouth when asking if we wanted anything more.  wow.  I support small business, unfortunately that service person really left an unpleasant air.
author: Jaime O.

description:
Solid and inexpensive no-frills sushi bar. Very reasonable pricing for the area. TINY restaurant, maybe 2 x tables for 2 and 2 x tables for 4 and the bar. Dinner for 2 was ~$40 and the soup, salad and rolls were all solidly good. Service was friendly.

Would recommend just for someone who wants to eat sushi at a reasonable price.
author: Jordan C.

description:
The service here is terrible! I sadly write this because the fish was fresh, the menu reasonable, and I loved the intimate setting. 

The waitress rolled her eyes when we requested more nigiri, she told us we could not have more lemon wedges because they had a limited supply and had to save it for future guests, and she was just plain rude. I'm usually pretty forgiving when it comes to service, but it was so horrible, I had to get this out there with the hopes that they might do something for future patrons. Unfortunately, I won't be one of them.
author: Happy D.

description: definitely good location for tourists. foods were very good and specially from sushi bar. it was not authentic Japanese though I really enjoyed.
author: Jenna K.

description:
Small place with good sushi. Cash only! So come prepared for that. 

This seems like a family-owned sushi bar, and they give you nice, personal service throughout the meal. We were there for lunch, and another group put in a big order right before us, so it took awhile for the first plates to come out. Once they started coming though, our waitress just kept bringing them out 1 roll at a time. 

Definitely works well to order a few rolls for the table and share. No B1G1 sushi roll specials or anything like that. 

Only disappointment was the edamame. Was overcooked and not served warm.

Also, there's one small bathroom outside of the restaurant. It's downstairs in the same building, and you'll have to ask the server for a key.
author: Matt T.

description:
We actually came here by mistake. Our reservation was for Akiko restaurant, but we walked into the wrong akiko! Who knew there are two restaurants both named Akiko within two blocks of each other?

We bit the bullet and ordered the  lizzy roll (avocado & salmon), double star roll (cucumber, avocado and unagi topped with hamachi and tuna), seaweed salad, eggplant and sashimi sampler. The food was pretty good. The fish tasted fresh and the sushi was decent sized.

The place is TINY. I think it only seats around 10. We probably saved ourselves $30 eating here. Not a bad little neighborhood place.
author: Alice W.

description:
This is not a roll review.

Akiko's sushi counter should be revoked. If you are craving authentic sushi, please pass. I came in to discover Akikos level of knowledge, unfortunately they had less than none.

I ordered a piece of nigiri, whatever was freshest - this is a great way to test the waters because you get to observe quality of rice, freshness & cut of fish . I was brought a trough of horse slop - literally 10 pieces of the most ugly, brutalized fish I've ever seen. The cuts would have been more precise if they were made by hurling the steaks into a ceiling fan. The waitress was surprised that I didn't try a thing - and still charged me 20$. Look at my pics but I warn you if you really care for Japanese cuisine then you might be offended.

No wonder I was the only customer...
author: Grayson K.

description: Never expected a tiny place can make high end style sushi. Very fresh and very tasteful. Can't wait to go back there again. Also super friendly chef and a very nice waitress.
author: Sylvia W.

description: Great little place (3-4 tables) specializing in sushi. Go sit at the bar and talk to the chef and you might just be surprised with some experimental dishes! The staff is super nice.
author: C A.

description: Cozy place to have some rolls and sake after work. I liked this place a lot because of they food. I had a bunch of nigiris and rolls.. The fish was fresh and tasty. Must try the crispy salmon skin roll and the spicy tuna roll (very good compared to other places). Definetly coming back for more!
author: Daniel T.

description:
Small place but big on hospitality (the restaurant only has 3 tables)!

I highly recommend the Sumo Roll (tuna and shrimp) for $11.00.  It was served with a smokey sauce with green onions and sesame oil.  Both my friend and I loved how innovative and tasty the roll was.

In fact, we were so pleased with the Sumo Roll that we gobbled it up in record time and wanted to try another.  After indicating our preference for raw fish, non-fried sushi, and surprises, the waiter brought a Rainbow Roll to the table.  Sadly this surprise was disappointing!  In fact it was so mediocre, I had time to practice my photography skills (see attached photo).

Furthermore, the seafood udon ($10.50) was bland...  hence the photography practice continued...

Free cabbage salad at the start of your meal and free sliced oranges at the end?  Surprise!  I liked this surprise... so no photos.  You get my drift?
author: Fei L.

description: Amazing, simple and high quality food. These folks care about what they do.  15 seats and you won't regret being in one of them.
author: Erik W.

description: I have been patronizing this establishment for decades. It never disappoints. The sushi is super fresh, artfully presented, and fairly priced. The staff is very accommodating for special orders. The tiny space is truly a gem as it only has about 5 tables. I happened to like the prior paint color scheme of soft greens over the current one, but everything else about the place remains stellar. I recommend giving it a try.
author: Sarah M.

description: I'm torn, I feel the sushi tasted fresh and yummy, but my spicy tuna roll almost had NO tuna in it. They add avocado and cucumber to their spicy tuna roll leaving no room for the tuna. I complained and the waitress looked surprised and made a comment to the sushi chef, but that was it. Little surprised nothing was done about it. Again all tasted good and I'd come back, but I'll make sure to ask for no cucumber or avocado in the roll.
author: Michael L.

description: Very small and quaint feel, made a good spot for date night. Get the white tuna nigiri! It is absolutely amazing!!
author: Ashley H.

description: It's a cute, tiny, cozy little spot. Confusing bathroom sitch. The servers are nice. The prices are right. The food is good, but not great. If this were Amherst, Mass, this would be my regular place.
author: Andrew K.

description:
Cheap, Great Food, Tiny Place

I've probably been to Akikos 20 or 30 times now so I thought I should write a review. In some ways I want to lie and say i's awful so that this tiny establishment doesn't fill up with yelpers. Oh well...

I may be somewhat biased when it come to Akikos since I literally live 30 seconds away. Regardless though I've been to a quite a few other Sushi Bars and they are never as good as Akikos. 

You really can't beat the prices, or the happy hour deals. $2.50 beers & Saki!? Edamame is $2.50 I think too.

Here is how my meal usually plays out...

Hot Tea (free!)
Small cabbage salad (free!)
Beer and/or Saki ($2.50 happy hour special)
Maki Roll - I usually get something basic like Spicy Tuna or Salmon, I had the Lizzy roll recently and really liked it too. Prices start around $6 & go up from there for 8 pieces. 
Free Sliced fruit (I've had orange, apple, pear, watermelon)

Sometimes I think they run out of the cabbage salad or the fruit at the end, no big deal though.

All in all this is a great place to check out. Because of the small size it's definitely better for smaller groups (5 people tops) & best for 1 or 2 people.
author: Noah K.

description: Be cautious. The price information is old and everything became expensive. Good atmosphere though.
author: K K.

description:
We hit the same sushi restaurant in LA regularly, and feel almost guilty going anywhere else, and usually aren't too thrilled with the sushi we get.  Our local spot is our spot!  But when you're out of town, and you're not sure where to go, Yelp is obviously your friend.  We wanted something walking distance that wouldn't be crazy expensive, and decided to roll the dice on Akiko's.

As other reviewers have said, the place is tiny.  It's so tiny, you feel like you're sitting in someone's living room as they're making sushi for you in their kitchen.  But, that was part of the appeal.  We arrived and there were two tables open, but the server asked that we sit at the bar.  (One group of 3 arrived for one of the tables and I believe she had a reservation - not quite sure if they stopped to put their name down earlier or if they did have a reservation, but the table was definitely reserved.)  We were fine with sitting at the bar.

Sushi was a little slow as only one sushi chef is working, but it was delicious.  The sumo roll was definitely my favorite, but the San Francisco maki roll came in a close second.  We always order a rainbow roll and gauge the freshness of the fish based off that, and it was delicious.  I was a little put off by the fact that the barbeque eel came out of a plastic bag - as in, not cooked in house - but we only had one roll with the eel and it was fine.

Akiko's is worth checking out if you're in the area and looking for a good sushi spot.  Definitely keep in mind the size, and the fact that there is only one sushi chef working, so if there are other patrons in the restaurant, you'll be waiting a while for your sushi rolls.
author: Ashleigh B.

description:
I never thought I'd ever give a one star rating - but it happened today.

We walk in and the server looks at us and continues his conversation and makes us wait despite there being two perfectly open tables. When we finally get seated, he plops the menus on the table and left. We immediately know what we want to order, but it takes the server 7 minutes to come to us because he continues his conversation. Let me say, 7 minutes is not THAT long, but considering this place only holds four tables and a sushi bar, and there were only 6 other people in the entire restaurant, it should have been sooner. He takes our order of 3 pieces of nigiri and the sashimi sampler and leaves. 

Then we wait... and wait... and wait. All the sushi chef and the server talk about is how their boss has people "after him." We thought the sushi was taking so long because they were putting together the sashimi sampler - but then we ended up waiting 20 minutes for 2 PIECES OF NIGIRI while they talked about their boss. Long story short, this place has horrible service, their quality of sashimi sincerely sucks, it takes forever to get served, not only were the Japanese food items spelled incorrectly, but regular words such as "bottle" were mispelled. If you're looking for sushi, go to any of the other Japanese restaurants a few blocks away.
author: Lindsey S.

description: My wife and I were staying at the Marriott across the street from them and decided to pay Akiko a visit. The sushi was amazing, service was 5 star and we both loved it.  It's a small place so make reservation.
author: Al A.

description: Please update your business hours. I went there today for lunch with my 80 year old grandmother only to see that you were closed.
author: Carol O.

description:
I live nearby and this is myy go-to sushi spot. I've probably been 50 times It's quaint and relaxing with free hot tea, and it's reasonably priced.

The fish is always fresh and great quality. We always always get the sashimi combo (10 piece chef's selection for ~$18). It used to be $15, but they raised the price recently and it's still worth it!

What we like here:
-Chef's select sashimi combination (10 piece sashimi)
-Double Star roll (slightly sweet and delicious)
-Sumo Roll (garlic yumminess)
-California roll (has japanese rice seasoning - furikake - for a unique take on a standard roll)
-Happy Hour until 7pm I think -- $2 seaweed salad and edemame!
author: Kat S.

description: They have decent affordable sushi.  You can definitely find better sushi at similar price point in the area.  The location itself is pretty small so you might have to wait a little to get seated.
author: Alex T.

description:
Sushi quality was good.  Knife work wasn't great.  Rolls were small in diameter.
Can't day I'm impressed.  Place is also very tight, especially if you get the seat blocking the door :-(
author: Ken Y.

description:
I travel to SF often for business and I'm always looking for good sushi around my hotel in Nob Hill. I've found a number of good places, but none as good as Akiko's. Their rolls are inventive, fresh and so delicious. I love that if I come here too late at night, they'll be out of certain fish. It's a bummer, but you know they're keeping it fresh. Prices are reasonable and the staff is really kind. 

If you eat in - the place is SMALL and no frills. Come for the food, not the decor.
author: Alison W.

description: I loved it. I mean really loved it- i am going back for more ( and this was a short trip to San Francisco) I had great service. The food was fresh and tasty. The waitress was VERY, very good. It is tiny. They take reservations- just call.
author: Karen S.

description:
First of all, this is not Akiko Restaurant-that's around the corner on Bush. That's where we were trying to go but dumb me, didn't read the yelp reviews more carefully :-).
This spot is tiny-fits 16 ppl max and being that we were in a hurry we didn't mind it for a quick bite to eat. We tried a couple of the chef specials--the spicy salmon was the best. I've had better sushi elsewhere so next time I'll try the Akiko we intended to go to and see how it measures up. Not a bad spot all in all for a quick bite.
author: Irina A.

description: Place is too small, waitress was lazy, and they charge you an automatic 18% service charge for serving 2 people, if u can even call that service! Make sure u are at the right place before placing your order or u will definitely regret it!
author: M-Foody B.

description: I just tried chicken donburi here and it wasn't authentic AT ALL. There are certain menus that tells if the chefs or restaurants at original and donburi is one of them. It is lost somewhere between Japan and China. Turned out that the owner (or the manager) is Chinese, of course. Doesn't have personality or character in the menu. Not coming back.
author: Tasha C.

description: Increased TIP! I put this $76 lunch on my company credit card.. I guess they thought they should take advantage and add $4 dollars.. With them doing this my entire expense report is off.. (the charge doesn't match the receipt) so I have to do a lot of paper work on my end and not get reimbursed for awhile. I've called twice and they say to call back at another time..
author: Bryn J.

description:
Stopped in for lunch before heading out of town. The joint is super tiny, but the sushi was amazing. The San Francisco Maki roll was ridiculously good...and after overspending at a lot of of other places, I couldn't believe how cheap the bill was.

I'll go back for sure
author: Pascal F.

description: THE BEST SUSHI IVE EVER HAD. I'm not just saying this. The fish is so fresh that it feels like it's melting in your mouth. There are about 5 tables, and I think the place can only hold 12 people. We didn't wait too long to be seated. We ordered the vegetable Udon (fresh broth, generous in size), and for specialty rolls: RCR, and one that had butter fish (it was a special of the day), and the Lizzy roll. Everything was perfect. It's literally just one sushi chef and a waitress but they are kind, accommodating, and attentive. Worth the visit. I'm coming back for sure.
author: J L.

description: These people are so rude!!! The food is good, the place is small and intimate but she forgot to give me my cabbage salad and soup with my roll. I had to remind her. Every time I asked for water she rolled her eyes. Very rude service, good food.
author: Alicia C.

description: This place is a chill, quaint japanese restaurant. The food was quite good -- I'm a huge fan of the CRC roll.  The waiter was really nice -- the place is small so he overheard us talk about ordering seaweed salad and just brought it out without us formally needing to order.
author: Mike V.

description: Nice sashimi dishes and eel don. The fish meat is fresh and tasty. And the rolls are delicious as well.
author: Leo Y.

description: No relation to the Akiko on Bush St. The place is very small, 3 tables, 3 bar seats and 1 sushi chef. They have a very basic fish/sushi menu (no uni). They had Amaebi but it doesn't come with the fried heads. They we also out of albacore, escolar (butterfish), and scallop. This place is very basic and no frills. For a little more money, you can find much better places blocks away...
author: Bryan L.

description:
Teeny, tiny sushi bar with great prices, nice people and great food!  The first trip made there was because it was convenient to the hotel.  The second trip (in a week) was becasue it was so fantastic the first time.  Go early to keep from having to wait, as there are only about 10 seats in this restaurant.

Miso soup and the spicy tuna roll is a good choice for less than $10.  Wow!
author: Laurie B.

description: Followed the reviews and they were right on... Small intimate sushi bar (3 sushi bar stools), got right in and had the best sushi if my visit to SF. The butterfish was incredible and the special off the charts. If you're not looking for a business setting but great sushi, this is the place.
author: Brooke H.

description:
If price is the only thing you care about, this is the sushi bar for you.
