Everything was luke warm:  What was supposed to be cold was luke warm, what was supposed to be hot was luke warm.  If you want a bowl of hot miso soup, keep walking.
author: Brian B.

description:
We decided to try this place since the other sushi place was too crowded. The place is quite tiny so I thought customer would get more attention from the serve.. but I was wrong. The serve forgot our order and still put it on our bill, I have to remind her to cancel it. 

For the food: I think we deserve better food quality for the price we paid. We ordered 1 tuna toro, 1 sashimi combo, 1 sumo roll, 1 hamachi roll and soup. Total bill came out for $99. 

I don't think i will come back here since there are couples better sushi places around the neighborhood
author: Hien P.

description:
I have been to a variety of sushi restaurants in San Francisco (and in LA, too) and this one is the best. 

It's tiny -- there are only four tables in the whole restaurant, and there's the same lady making all the sushi every time I go. But, it's delicious. 

The sushi is incredibly fresh and everything is made to order. My absolute favorite roll is the Sumo Roll, tuna, shrimp, lemon, garlic, heaven. 

Favorite sushi bar in the city and totally reasonably priced.
author: Lauren F.

description:
I'm a firm believer that besides the food, customer service directly affects and defines a dining experience. That being said, mad props to the business woman/chef, and server at Akikos. She was was a multitasking diva who was unbelievably attentive, sweet, and made the best chicken udon hands down. 
          
        For $8.95 you get a hearty serving of udon soup that does not disappoint. The chicken was all white meat, it contained fresh veggies, and tofu. The flavor did not come from excessive salt doses, but rather from the  chicken broth itself, and was perfect for the cold weather.
           
        Once you're done, the awesome chef/server diva will intuitively sense you are satisfied, and with a bright smile will offer you a to go container.
     
    Side note: I feel the need to comment on the container itself. Too many restaurants skimp on to-go containers, opting for flimsy plastic-lid opening-pieces of *** that break open or leak. Not Akikos!!  Theirs are extremely durable and kept my udon safe as well as fresh. Container rant aside, Akiko's is a must try =]
author: Gabriella C.

description:
I have passed this place innumerable times, and only recently had the chance to come here for lunch. On my visit, I was impressed. This place is a little funky, and a lot unique.

The space is tiny. Like, even by San Francisco standards tiny. Just a handful of tables, and some seats at the bar. If you need to use the bathroom you have to leave the restaurant, go through the residential part of the building, go downstairs into the basement and then use a cell-like toilet. My advice is to avoid using the toilet here.

The food was really good, and very reasonable. Sitting at the bar, I watched the sushi chef do her work, and she's good. The fish seemed reasonably fresh, and our rolls tasted good.
author: Wes T.

description: For some reason, "fresh", is the word that comes to mind when I eat here and that's the number one priority for me when eating sushi.  This place is a hidden gem (jade of course)!
author: Megan Z.

description: They were super rude. Said they were full, then refused to help us when we were searching for another venue.
author: Nicki P.

description:
Worst. Service. Ever. 

We went in, sat down, ordered. 40 minutes after that, my friend was the first to get her sushi roll. 30 minutes passed by, my other friend get his order. Another 30 minutes later, my gf gets her order. So I'm sitting there wondering, "Yo, I ordered one roll. ONE. EFFIN. ROLL." While this is all going on, the waiter is telling me that my order will be out soon and that they're making it. He probably said this about 3-4 times with no apologies. As you can already tell, I am super pissed off. Like any starving person would be. After a whomping 1hr and 40min, I then get my sushi roll. They offered it as on the house. As if a roll of spicy tuna with some weak shit sauce on top would make up for all that waiting. Too mad/stubborn to eat, I ended up giving the roll to my friends at the table. Left, without saying a word. Oh and here's the kicker, THERE WERE ONLY 4 OTHER GUESTS! 2 guys at the bar and 1 couple! It's SUSHI! RAW FISH! HOW LONG DOES IT TAKE?! I'm pretty sure they were fishing for my fish out back or something.

tl;dr: Waited 1hr 40min for 1 sushi roll.


Hey Owner, please seppuku yourself. Thanks.
author: Vinue V.

description: We were looking for a good sushi place while on vacation in San Francisco. We read about Akikos and thought we'd give it a try. It's a small, intimate place with maybe 4 tables. We weren't sure if there would be room for us, but we walked in and were immediately seated. There was one server and one chef there around 8 pm on a weekday. Our order was promptly taken and our food was brought out quickly. We asked for a substitute for the nori wrapping but they were out, so the chef rolled the sushi with no sheet. The rolls stayed together, no mess, and the sushi was good! I also ordered the chicken teriyaki with rice which was very tasty. Would recommend this place to any of our friends visiting the area.
author: Amanda B.

description:
This is NOT the same as the other more famed/reviewed Akiko's Restaurant nearby, but still delicious.  Akiko's Restaurant is a bit more upscale while Akiko's Sushi Bar is small and homey.  There's very limited seating here so I would not recommend for groups larger than 4, and definitely call in advance for reservation/walk-in availability.

We ordered a bunch of rolls but I could tell that the nigiri/sashimi would be excellent on its own.  The fish was fresh and buttery, and the rice was soft and well seasoned.

Despite what a lot of reviews say, I thought service was fine for what it was-- one chef and one waitress.  This restaurant is Chinese (Cantonese)-owned, so that might explain the less than top-notch service.
author: S L.

description:
Surprising cheap when It seems to be in a prime location. Maybe I don't know san francisco too well.

It's a small place, so I thought this might be a good sign for a Japanese place. Nothing special although it does have a nice ambience. I tried the 18 piece maki, salmon, tuna, avocado. Was okay. The miso soup was good to help warm me up.
author: Robin D.

description: Taste good for "American sushi". A chief is serving 15 people capacity. You can enjoy nice sushi, chatting and even waiting long.
author: Jerry M.

description:
Meh...

For the amount of money I paid, I could've gotten more/better sushi elsewhere...
author: Anthony N.

description: I feel gypped on the quantity of fish! Totally more rice than fish! Their stickers on the window indicates that they take card but then they insisted on having cash. With so much competition you can do a lot better.
author: Brian P.

description: Terrible service. It took 55 minutes for them to complete our to go order. They completed another persons to go order before they got to ours. It seems like they had priority making the dine in customers orders before ours. Will never repeat.
author: Natalie M.

description:
Worst Sushi Bar is SF!
I work by this place  and decided to try out one day.  The place itself looks pretty kool and friendly, but that's where it stops.
First of all, the service was SLOW!  I went during lunch and the place was busy, and they only had 2 waiters.  
I ordered the teriyaki beef, and the beef was undercooked and cold!  The rice was also cold!  I was shocked that they would serve the food like this.  This was the worst teriyaki beef I ever had.
But the worst part was the unagi nigiri!  The unagi should've been served warm, but it was also served cold and dry!  It was the most horrible nigiri ever.  I was so close to reporting them to the SF Health Department.  Yes, it really was that bad.
With SF being such a sushi mecca... do not go here!  Lastly, for the food they were serving, it was definitely overpriced.
author: Emmett B.

description: Rolls were good, nothing to write home about. Hole in the wall with little atmosphere. Website and Yelp says they take American Express, which they do not.
author: Jason M.

description: Loved it. What a cute, tiny place! Fresh sushi. Friendly staff.
author: Mark S.

description: Nice little place that is so small it reminds me of the Tokyo places. The quality is OK but not super. Ambiance and service are the lead here. Stick with the regular sushi and sashimi's to have a good dinner. The "special" rolls are not that tasty. Udon dishes are also nice!
author: C S.

description: I discovered this tiny little sushi place by accident whilst walking past and seeing a line of people waiting outside. I was looking for a place for dinner and walked in and luckily since I was in a group of one they had a space for me at the bar. I can't remember exactly everything I ordered but the food was so delicious I kept on ordering! It was amongst the very best sushi I've had and I've had it in a lot of places and countries. But this was divine. The standout piece was the Hamachi Belly nigiri but the Salmon Belly nigiri  well as the crispy shrimp roll and the chef's sashimi platter were all excellent.The aforementioned Hamachi was just mindblowing in its freshness, texture and taste and the portions of fish were large. I liked it so much I went twice more in the next 3 days and spent more everytime! I'd say you can have a good meal here if you are on a budget but if you are willing to spend in the 60-100 dollar range (including tips and taxes and all drinks) you can have a mindblowing experience. I certainly did. And both the head chef and the stunning young waitress were both super-friendly and provided great service. A definite little gem.
author: Asif J Z.

description: Their food are so delicious! Their sushi is so fresh too! They only have four table and one bar. Very small room. Hard to walk in from door to the table that we were seating in. The four table was quickly seated. Friendly server. They do have wifi. You better go in before 11am for lunch or it would get crowd. Definitely will go there again.  Also they don't have tempura on the menu.
author: Agnes B.

description: Food is okay but service can  be better.  The waitress looks angry the whole time and she mixed up my order twice!
author: Katie P.

description:
One word: Forgettable.

There are plenty of little pockets of delicious restaurants in SF that look like a hole in the wall but are really a treasure... this is really just a hole in the wall.

If you MUST stop to eat here, though, their eggplant appetizer is tasty, but there is nothing outstanding about this place. Keep walking and just about any other restaurant you'll walk into will have better food.
author: Lesley-Anne L.

description: We stumbled upon this treasure. Best meal we had in San Francisco and also the least expensive and most pleasant atmosphere.
author: Joan J.

description: Horrible.  We should have checked the ratings before we ate here.  The fish was not fresh, and the chef has definitely not been trained in the art of sashimi or sushi preparation.  It looked like he just took a hacksaw to the fish.  It didn't matter anyways, since the fish was inedible. Ironically, the only tasty portion of the meal was the (free) pickled cabbage.  Everything else was a health hazard. Luckily we ordered very little, and then ate at another restaurant.  Would not eat here again--apparently it is possible to find indecent cuisine in the city.
author: Joyce M.

description:
Sushi was good - fresh and fast.

Service was not good - stale and slow. Server mixed up an order, and she was generally inattentive. No announcement that the one sushi chef was closing the kitchen before closing time, so when we wanted another roll we were SOL. No ice cream could be served either. The server's long, dirty fingernails dipped into the food when she was setting it onto the table. Not appetizing.

Price was acceptable - good value but not cheap, though cheap sushi is generally not what I'm after. Give me the good stuff!

I'd go back during the day when the kitchen closing early wouldn't be an issue and when the server was more alert and hygienic.

But the sushi itself? A-OK indeed.
author: Jen S.

description:
When I first walked into Akiko's I was surprised by how small the space was -- the restaurant had at most 15 seats, four tables. The staff seemed to consist of one sushi chef, the hostess/cashier/waitress, and one kitchen chef.

When I arrived with my friend late on a Friday night (around 9pm), they had run out of spicy tuna and closed their main kitchen, meaning we could only order sushi. By the time we had finished our meal, the restaurant had run out of everything except for salmon. 

We ordered the Philadelphia combo (16-piece) and San Francisco roll (14-piece), and were served salmon in each instead of tuna. The touch of smoked salmon in the Philadelphia roll made it my favorite of the night, although both orders were tasty. I was also pleased with the complementary tea, mini-salad, and miso soup, all of which were pleasantly mild but still flavorful. Overall, the meal was nice, but not spectacular.

My friend and I evenly split the bill, which came out to $11.15 each without tip -- not bad considering we were hunting for a place to eat around Union Square so late at night. We were both full after we left the restaurant.
author: Rex X.

description: Akiko's is incredible.  It is tiny, authentic, and quiet.  I ordered the sushi and sashimi assortment, which came with a delicious cabbage salad and a miso soup to start.  The sashimi was ridiculous - fresh and almost buttery in texture... I'm having heavenly flashbacks just thinking about it.  The spicy tuna roll was the best one I've ever had, and I've had a lot of spicy tuna.  I would come back to Akiko's every day if I could.  Great sake as well.  There are only a few tables, so make a reservation.
author: Rachel A.

description:
I'm always happy to pay for a great meal, definitely for sushi. So I specifically asked for a recommendation for a traditional sushi joint with great fish.

To be fair, it was Monday, so Akiko being open was a bad sign. But the menu was great, with a lot of interesting white fish from summer snapper to amber jack.  

The biggest problem is probably the service. The service staff seemed... angry? I was alone, and asked to sit at the sushi bar. Once sat (15 min, even though there were two empty seats and infact, they sat me in one of them eventually), I had to wait 10 minutes and ask for a menu. Then, ask for the specials menu and drink menus, and when I only got one, I had to ask for the drink menu a third time. Nonetheless, the sushi chef, though busy, seemed to be skillful and friendly, and the menu was impressive. 

The service continued to be horrible. This was consistent with those around me. My neighbors soy sauce was empty, and I reached to offer them mine only to realize it too, was empty. I had to flag down my waiter to order a drink. He was just rude... I had wanted to ask the sushi chef what fish he recommended, and he insisted, "I take all the orders". No prob, dude, but I'd still like to ask a question. 

The sushi chef was incredibly nice and asked what I wanted, and as usual, I asked for omakase (whatever you suggest). He asked what I liked and didn't, I told him whatever he wanted and then I waited another 45 minutes. Everyone around me was served items, and I just waited. He routinely asked me what I liked, and I'd expect something to come, and nada. Then, suddenly, a plate full of fish arrived, about 12 pieces of fish, a relatively good assortment, including uni. But the presentation was really meh... I'm not expecting a lot, but a little garnish would be nice.  But that seems nitpicking because... 

the fish itself wasn't good. The uni was actually gooey, meaning it was no longer good. It was melting on the plate. I didn't eat it. The salmon was good, but not cut right. He hadn't even cut the slices all the way through. Doing so with chopsticks is tough even for me. The yellowtail was good, but that was it. Everything else tasted tough, and a little off. It was like it was all frozen. The slices were entirely too thick, Sashimi should melt in your mouth. This was chewy. 

The kitchen was cranking out typical sushi rolls and people seemed happy with them, so perhaps I was just asking too much. But, these things happen and the sushi chef was friendliy enough. then the bill arrived. 

For one small plate of sashimi and a $15 sake, the bill was 68$. I'm thrilled to pay that much and more for a good meal, but this was not one of them. That number is obscene for 12 slices of fish. 

I paid, I smiled. I left. 

The restaurant has no email address to contact them at. I'll call tomorrow to complain.
author: Amanda B.

description:
The closest sushi joint to my office, I'm not at all perturbed by the cutesie size of this restaurant. The servers are always nice, and the food is a-ok!

I always order the lunch combo: 8 pieces assorted sushi, miso soup, salad, and free hot tea. It's a very light but satisfying meal, and the fish is always fresh. I end up paying $11-$13 total for my meal, which is pretty decent given that I'm at Union Square.

The ambiance is awesome, with a window facing the street and natural light that makes you feel quite relaxed. I bring my book here for lunch, and sometimes stay for an extended amount of time just because of how homey it feels (unless there are incoming guests waiting for a table, of course).

Definitely dependable for fresh fish and simple sushi. I have yet to try any special rolls here, but I presume they're just as great.

Bottom Line:

A great sushi bar if you're eating alone on a lunch break from work. But, if you're with a big group of people, perhaps try Sushi Toni that's about a block and a half northeast of there.
author: Gaille C.

description: Small restaurant with only about 4 tables. Server lady was friendly and helpful with the menu. Everything from the miso soup to the ahi tuna appetizer to the specialty sushi rolls were fresh and delicious. Prices were pretty good. 3 of us feasted for about $65. I would definitely visit Akiko's for excellent sushi in the Union Sq area of San Francisco.
author: Jeremy B.

description: Was not very happy with the service or the quality of the food. I am pretty sure that they gave me salmon when I asked for tuna.
author: Melody C.

description:
What a nice little find!

Very small sushi spot in Union Square SF.  
I believe that there are only four tables and a sushi bar with about 3-4 seats.

We had three different rolls (sumo, lizzy and i forgot the other).  Plus edadmame and a roasted eggplant appetizer.  

Delicious and very reasonable prices. 

The hostess is super cute and has a charming personality.

They pace your entrees, as there is only one sushi chef.

Overall, nice place.  Cheers!
author: Derek N.

description: I used to go to the "old" Akiko's and could always get a spot at the sushi bar. Now, reservations at least two weeks in advance are required and the sushi is frankly, no better than other local sushi bars. I've shown up here without a reservation, place only half full, with 8 open sushi bar seats at 8pm on a Wednesday, only to be told "reservations only."  Bunch of BS.
author: Lindy H.

description:
We found this place after a day of walking around the mall and it's literally a hole in the wall! It seriously looks like it used to be someone's tiny SF living room.

It was SO HOT in there, there was no ventilation AT ALL. It felt like a sauna and I just wanted to leave but I was so hungry...

The food was good, we got the vegetarian combo and the sushi combo. Both were good and the sushi was fresh. Nothing too memorable however, so we probably won't be coming back especially since we're Oakland dwellers and there's great sushi on this side of the Bay!
author: Jennifer Y.

description:
Strolled in for a beer and some late lunch sushi around 130 with an uncle. He's vegetarian and said there were plenty of options for him, so with a shrug I agreed. 

This place is tiny. The size of a closet tiny. There's maybe space for 15 people in this place and one table basically keeps the doorway hard to get to (maybe a fire code violation.)

The service was ok, we didn't see any open tables and we were about to leave and the waiter was attune with who was ready to go and said that we'd have a table almost immediately.

After being seated we were brought hot tea and then asked promptly if we wanted something to drink. Maybe it was the fact the place was small but the waiter was on point. We ordered a large Sapporo to split, and for five dollars we each got almost a full beer to drink.

On to the food: it was fresh but not memorable. Cheap but not too cheap.

Service was snappy until we wanted the check.

I bet there are much better places to eat at in SF but if you wander by, the place has some open tables pop in. As long as you don't expect the best, you won't be sad because it won't be your worst.
author: Kalyan P.

description:
I hate this place.   Some of the most  forgettable sushi I have ever had.  They play crappy 90's Adult Soft Rock.  Get  with the times and turn off that crap. I dont understand why Asian restaurants play crappy American music, play the music of you country, thats what Im eating thats what I want to hear!

This place was soo bootsy. Fish was not great.    The place looks so quaint and inviting from the inside but skip it.  If you kinda like sushi, this may do for you.  If you really like sushi, skip it. Go to Sakana on Post instead.  Better and fresher fish.
author: Hillary L.

description:
I was hungry I wanted sushi but didn't want to go far from my hotel, my feet and knees were killing me from tackling the city for the past four days.  I turn to my crackberry and check yelp.  I put in "sushi bar", my hotel address and 4 block radius, I was tired I didn't want to go far.  Nine places popped up I immediately eliminated four of them for being 3 stars.  Of the other five one was eliminated because it wasn't open yet, it was a little after 5 pm and I wanted to eat now.  Of the remaining four I found the one closest to me and picked that one.

It was a tiny place and I had a bit of a hard time finding the front door but once I did I was glad.  Four tables with four seats at the sushi bar, see it's tiny.  Lucky for me I was able to grab one of the two a tables for two.

Tea and water were given along with the menu as I review the menu I drink some tea, good tea I might add.  I decide what I wanted and place my order: disco maki, San Francisco maki and eel temaki.

As I'm waiting for my order a pickled cabbage salad of some sort in presented before me.  I take a bite, I'm not sure if I like it or not so I take another and another and by the time I reach the bottom of the bowl I decided I did like it.  It was a little sweet and a little sour but it worked well together with the cabbage.

The San Francisco maki (spicy albacore and krab) was the first to arrive and it was delish the spicy albacore was joined by some fresh avocado and the two just melted together wonderfully and the krab and roe on top wasn't bad either.  I quickly ate the 8 pieces and wished for more.

Next up was the disco maki (spicy tuna and eel) it looked fantastic and was fantastic and with each bite there was a disco dance in my mouth yum yum yum. 

My eel temaki was the last to arrive it looked lonely on its plate so I was nice and let it meet my mouth and I don't now how it felt but my mouth sure was happy. Their eel was wonderful, loved every bite.

After my plates were cleared they brought me a plate of fresh orange slices, they were juicy and delicious and a nice after sushi treat.

There was only one big, tiny, thing that annoyed me the music.  See they had the radio playing and there was so much static it was killing me, it kept cutting in and out I was getting really annoyed because they just left it and acted like nothing was happening. 

But the three ladies working provided great service and the food was delightful and cheap, all my food was less than $20 I couldn't believe it so I left a happy girl.
author: Me H.

description: Great sushi great service. It's a locals place so it's small. Home made wasabi and hand crafted sushi. Excellent saki and great prices. Service is great and the place is small enough to get the waitress' attention at any time. Cheers
author: Ashley L.

description:
Hole in the wall place.  Took a chance.

Got the assorted sashimi set.  Borderline the worst sashimi i've ever had.  I guess that's why it's only $15.

I was there at 9pm on a wednesday, so maybe that was it.  But it seriously tasted pretty aweful...  sad times...  

One of the places that make me wonder how they have a decent yelp review.  Or if their quality just went down after the first opened.
author: Steven F.

description: The Food is Good and their Service is Good too .me and my boyfriend was enjoy those delicious sushi. Good job Akiko we love it！ at last if the room size can be bigger will be A+
author: Min Q.

description:
Went here for lunch today, relatively good.

The place is really small - only 3 tables, 2 of which only seat 2, one which is basically part of the door itself.  However, traffic seemed pretty light for lunch hour, and most patrons seemed to be there for pickup.

Our waiter was very friendly, and had a good rapport with the sushi chef, they kept things lively with customers while remaining polite and giving me and my girlfriend time to ourselves.

Orders came with a free cabbage + furikake (seaweed, sesame seeds, sugar, salt) salad, which was a nice touch.  The waiter was very attentive and offered us extra miso soup to go with our dishes.

Food was relatively authentic - the vegetable udon was light on salt and had a decent amount of actual substance, which is better than most.  Noodles were typical, but that's neither a good thing or a bad thing.  I'd recommend katanaya if you are looking for better noodles.  My tekka-don (tuna sashimi over rice) was quite good.  This is one of the few places that has served me proper sushi rice with my sashimi donburis, as opposed to most who will serve you normal hot rice (you should only get that with chicken and eel).

Price was decent for the area, but more than I would have paid for this food at a "great price" restaurant.

Certainly a good place for a quick, quiet lunch.
author: Justin L.

description:
Definitely the freshest tasting sushi in the city. Akiko's is a very small, clean and cozy restaurant with phenomenal food. My favorites are: spicy salmon maki (melts in your mouth) tuna tartar( topped with avocado and lemon, so delicious) albacore donburi (always excellent, and they don't mind substituting for other ingredients) 
I come here every time I am in the union square area which is quite often and never get tired of this restaurant. They always serve the best tasting fruit after you finish your meal. I highly recommend Akiko's to everyone!!
author: Natalie B.

description:
At akikos...the place is incredibly small..it seats 16 people. The server was very nice when I entered..all tables were filled and she asked me to please wait since someone was paying and about to leave. 

It was Sunday after 830, which is a happy hour time for this place. I ordered the 3 dollar seaweed salad and 2.50 house saki. The seaweed salad was a good portion and tasty. I've been some places where its a little slimy but this was very fresh! 

I tried the lizzy roll with cucumber and asparagus and a 16 piece roll came out!   Wowza! the lemon made it really fresh and tasty.  Tea came with the meal hot and yummy.

I thought it quaint and the service was great.  As a solitary traveler, I felt at home eating good food and reading  and people watching.  I'd go there again when I go back to my conference in San Fran!
author: Amy M.

description: nice big pieces of fish, but tuna was tough and stringy, and the sushi-sashimi "assortment" was nearly half salmon.
author: Amanda R.

description: Sushi was great but really poor service while we waited. A party of 2, 1 & 3 came in after us and they all got their food after us. That needs to be fixed! Sushi was 5 star worthy but device was 0 stars.  HOWEVER the reason for 5 stars and not 2 or 3 was my wife left her wallet on the chair and didn't realize it was gone until about 3hrs later and they had it!
author: Jonathan C.

description: Beyond ridiculous value service and quality.  Best hidden gem in SF.  Come here with a small group only.  Limited seating. And try the house sake - it is delicious!
author: Joe D.

description:
Literally a hole in the wall but decent and not overpriced for where it is. But if you're a claustrophobic then I don't recommend because place is small. If you're a foodie who's willing to try new food then it's worth a try.

Every sushi house has to have a few house dishes that makes them stand out from others and this place is no exception. Had this sushi plate that looked almost egg rollish but was spicy tuna tartar on a bed of greens with a balsamic vinegaritte. Thats the one dish I remember vividly. 

Don't get me wrong though the other rolls we had were worth it too to go and try out. Try out stuff that you've never seen at other places' menus. Yes it may not be good but what if its out of this world? You could have missed out.

Definite recommend this place as a lunch outing,
author: Holden L.

description: I really have no idea why Akikos only has 3.5 stars. This is without a doubt one of, if not the best sushi restaurants I have ever been to. A tiny whole in the wall that will set a sushi standard that will be hard to beat. It has great service,  no unnecessary frills and the most flavorful fresh and delicious fish in Sf. Take the time to check this place out and you will not be sorry. Listen to the waitresses recommendations!
author: Elizabeth T.

description:
My wife and I had lunch there today and it was truly one of the best Sushi bars we have experienced. Well priced, intimate and today was all local people. For taste it was way better than the Uber expensive Morimoto in Napa valley were we live.
This will now be our regular stop on all our visits to The City.
author: David R.

description: Love Akiko's and always make it a point to come here when in San Francisco. GREAT food that tastes fresh! The service is friendly and the atmosphere is nice. Very small interior though, so call ahead or plan to take out!
author: Markus B.

description: Great food! It's a tiny place, seating is very limited. Come early or you'll have to wait outside for at least 30 minutes to an hour. It can be a romantic place as the seats are very close to each other. It's a nice find in the middle of chaos.
author: Jacqueline L.

description: We stayed at the JW Marriott Union Square and decided to walk across the street and try out this place for dinner.  The restaurant is really small (4-5 tables).  We waited about 10 minutes to sit at the sushi bar.  Service was fast and pleasant.  We ordered a dragon roll and double star roll.  Both were fresh and fantastic!  We will definitely return the next time we are in San Fran!
author: Tedi F.

description:
This used to be a popular place with a line of people waiting for a table. Not any more. These days, with a different owner, it is the most disappointing "Japanese" restaurant I've been to. I'm half Japanese, so trust me, I tried many Japanese restaurants. 
The tempura udon I ordered consisted of over fried, bitter tasting veggies with two skinny shrimp, fried so long they could pass as beef jerky, overcooked udon noodles and tasteless soup base. A bowl of hot water with a tablespoon of soy sauce would be better.

Definitely not going back.
author: Koichiro K.

description: Overall experience was good. The sushi was good and menu offered a good selection of rolls and combos. The restaurant is very very tiny, I would not recommend this place for a party larger than two.  Service was ok and the speed that the sushi was prepared was acceptable but not quick.
author: Marty L.

description:
First off let me say that this place is very small. 3 tables and three seats at the sushi bar. They have one sushi chef, one server, and one kitchen person.

 Next let me say that the prices here are very very reasonable for the location. And the sushi is very fresh which is always a plus.

 They have many great rolls and happy hour rocks with beers at 2.50. Not the best sushi ever but very fresh and great prices. Service is slow....one chef.

 Overall if you are in Union Square go here if you want sushi just don't come with a group of more the 4.
author: Norm H.

description: I was sadly disappointed... Was this the same place that I liked not too long ago? Service was slow... And sushi was completely different from what I remembered last time. So no, I will not be coming back:(
author: Myra M.

description:
They have the absolute BIGGEST sushi rolls I have ever encountered! HUGE. Do not plan on being able to stuff your face with more than one roll unless you are sharing (which, thankfully, I did). 

We had the 49ers Roll, the Philadelphia Roll, and the Sweet Potato Roll in addition to some Miso Soup. While the soup was nothing to write home about (Miso Soup rarely is), the 49ers roll was splendid! 

The Philadelphia Roll (Salmon, Cream Cheese, Cucumber) was excellent-- one of the best I've had (and it's my go-to roll), with some of the creamiest cream cheese around and a generous portion of salmon.

The 49ers roll was a California roll with Spicy Tuna and Caviar on top, and it was freakin' magnificent. Excellent texture, taste-- EVERYTHING. This sushi made me wish that my stomach was bigger so I could eat MOAR.

I didn't eat the sweet potato roll, but mom assures me that it was delicious. Let me tell you, if the other rolls were big, this puppy was big-ER. Took mom too bites to shovel it into her mouth, but she assured me that it was worth it.

All in all, a pretty great place for a random find!
author: Katrina R.

description: Hours online said they were open and when we got there they were still setting up and getting ready. We asked if we could sit down while we wait since weve been walking around a lot and they refused, even though the open sign was up too. When we finally got to sit down 20 mins later we saw how small and cute the place and how nice the waitress was, but the food wasnt all that. The rolls were super small and when my friend asked for the spiciest roll they had he said it wasnt even spicy at all. My friend also ordered lemon water and received plain water. Cute place, but definately not somewhere id go back to. They accepted card too when we went and the it was kinda pricey for how small the rolls were.
author: Audra B.

description: I also got confused over this place and meant to go to the other Akiko's that I heard had the freshest fish in SF. So it's pretty funny actually because as I was eating this sushi I couldn't help but wonder why everyone said it was so fresh and it turned out to be the wrong place. Fish was not the best. I always eat the tuna/maguro first so I know how fresh the place is. It had that little sour taste that tells you it's not fresh. So unfortunately I went in with the high standards and expectations of another restaurant and was disappointed. One of these restaurants should change their name.
author: Marcus M.

description:
Absolute best sushi I've ever had and at great prices.  The sumo roll is fantastic.  You get extras with your sushi too, like a little salad and some fruit for dessert.

And like everyone says, the place is tiny, tinier than you're picturing.
author: Sean C.

description:
This is a great little find. 

The sake sashimi was a nice cut of fish, and served at the proper temperature. Declicious!

The Volcano roll was not on the menu as others mentioned, but in its place I strongly recommend the Doublestar Roll (Snowcrab & B.B.Q. Eel, avocado topped with 3 slices of maguro, 3 slices of hamachi).

If you're looking for something a bit off the beaten path, but near The Square, this should definitely peak your interest. The food is even so good that it's worth making this a destination location. 

Only drawback is the size of the place with only 4 tables, but no need to be shy. Share a table with someone. Part of its charm is the size too.
author: Jeffrey R.

description: DELISH! Very satisfied! Friendly, quick and very delish service!
author: Janelle E.

description:
My rule of thumb when it comes to sushi bars: must be either a hole in the wall or the most elegant, ridiculously upscale establishment.  

Akiko's is the the former: a pale robin's egg blue tiny box with about four tables and a small bar.  The female sushi chef is a goddess who knows what flavors highlight the fish without covering it with gloopy, overpowering sauces.  

The seafood udon bowl tastes like the sea (in the best possible way). The sake, hamachi, and toro nigiri are highlights, as well as the Lizzy roll, with a perfect hint of lemon to bring out the silken perfection of the salmon.  

I always love that now matter how long its been since my gf and I have been there, the women always recognize us and are so friendly.  Just a lovely, unpretentious sushi experience.
author: Christina H.

description:
You know, I really wanted to give Akiko's more chances than they deserved.

It used to be my go-to sushi spot because I lived right by Union Square last year. Usually a hit-and-miss, lately it has been all misses - and why is the fish so darn COLD all the time? 

Even when my experience was a hit, I would only give the place 3 stars. Last time I went, I felt very sick afterwards and vowed never to go back. And I don't think I ever will.
author: Anna H.

description:
TIny hole in the wall. Extremely small space--not for you if you get claustrophobic or prefer more of a "vibe". Also, this place is not to be confused with Akiko's on Bush. While I heard the server say they are "related", I find no similarities. Their menus are completely different!

This place is good for sushi on a budget. I had the Lizzy roll combo. It was ok. The combo came with a cabbage salad and miso soup. Cabbage salad serving was very tiny but ok. The miso was a little bland.

Not sure if I'd be back. Super small spaces like that just don't really do it for me. And I prefer more turnover in a sushi restaurant, for obvious reasons...
author: Rosie S.

description:
The small, intimate setting of Akiko's makes it suitable for a romantic dinner out -- couple that with it's affordable prices and it's deliciously fresh sushi and you may have found the perfect spot for a romantic dinner out.

Now, I am in no way a sushi expert. I'm more then happy chowing down on a roll or two of spicy tuna roll from Safeway -- so when my girlfriend brought me here I let her take full control of what we ordered. Their Sumo Roll was to die for. I'd always added squeezed lemon to my sushi, but the incorporation of fresh lemon and garlic was heavenly. In fact, my least favorite roll was the spicy tuna roll she ordered to satiate my sushi cravings.

I will definitely be returning.


TL;DR -- Amazing Happy Hour deals, fresh fish, delicious sushi, and intimate setting. KInd of everything one looks for in a sushi restaurant. Side note: this place has no ice -- whatsoever.
author: Gabriel S.

description: A tiny, hidden gem in San Francisco. Went there with my girlfriend and was amazed how incredibly small the place was, only a few seats total. The prices were excellent and the sushi was fantastic and fresh. We were both stunned at how amazing overall the food and friendly was of this little gem. A must if you're in downtown San Francisco.
author: Dana S.

description: We were visiting from NY and happened to find this place on our last night. It was tiny, yes, but relaxing and accommodating.  Our  son had the chicken udon soup. It was huge and delicious. We had a variety of sushi and sashimi-the chefs choice was outstanding, the rest wonderful. Great little find. Definitely go-just make a reservation!
author: Sam L.

description:
I walked past this place looking for an interesting restaurant - and decided to pop in.  I wear a size 14 shoe, and my feet almost didn't fit inside.  The restaurant is smaller than a shot of sake.  

Immediately, given the size of the place (maybe 4 tiny tables), my expectations increased.  In my experience traveling in Japan, the smaller the sushi place, the better the sushi/sake. That said, it missed expectations a bit...  the service was good - the young server was kind, prompt, and she smiled as she joked in Chinese with the chef and colleague in the back.  

yes, it's not authentic sushi - but given the affordable price, and the decent quality - I have a difficult time complaining.  As the Yelp stars say, it's A-OK.
author: Kurt W.

description:
I went back and the waitress was much nicer. Its strange, however that sometimes you get a cabbage salad with vinegar and other times miso soup. I'm not going to complain though because both are delicious.

The issue I had this time was that my sake sashimi was a little too cold - almost as it had just gotten out of the freezer. I'd totally rather my fish cold than too warm, but it was a little unappealing. After I let it sit for a few minutes, it thawed and tasted great.
author: Emily K.

description:
Came here when we were in town last weekend. It was a short walk from our hotel and proved to be a diamond in the rough. 
This place is tiny but offers a surprising variety of options. There are 4 tables - 2 four tops and 2 two tops. Oh and four seats at the sushi bar.

The rolls were pretty good and well priced. I had the sashimi salad which was good but too small for a meal, and not enough seaweed salad in it (my favorite part!).
author: Lucy S.

description:
After having toured around and looked at the menu of a dozen of Japanese restaurants in the neighborhood , I was attracted by this tiny and cute establishment.  Only a few tables inside, but enough to have me seated.  

No special dishes here, just conventional sushi, sashimi, rolls and yakitori.  After a decent but a bit too-sweet little cabbage salad appetizer, a disappointingly cold miso soup and a long awaiting (more than 30 min!), my sushi-sashimi mix came.  Minus: small portion. Plus: the quality was excellent, particularly the albacore tuna sashimi and the caramelized eel sushi.  A good but not unforgettable (unlike the once delighting Sushiman's) temaki with spicy scallop followed. Here I honestly did not appreciate the use of spicy mayonese instead of some more refined seasoning.  I would have loved to end my meal with a scoop of green ice tea, but there was none left. 

To summarize, attention to details doesn't fully belong here, the food ranges from mediocre to very good, but I could come back a couple of times.
author: Andrea L.

description:
Just finished a 3 day trip flying all over and was craving sushi. So I dragged the boyfriend to Akiko's Sushi. Since it is right smack dab near Union Square we decided to cab it from SOMA. This place was literally a hole in the wall. It reminded me of a tiny Japanese restaurant in Japan. 

The server was extremely nice, but forgot my miso soup, but no big deal. Their FRESH SALMON NIGIRI is nice fatty and fresh!!!! Highly recommend. The NIGORIZAKE is only $6.50 for a large. The Lizzy Roll had a lemon puree that was not very good, so would not recommend.

My boyfriend ordered the Donburi Bowl, which is actually served on a plate with the rice on the side. The Donburi Chicken Bowl tasted healthy and had an assortment of vegetables that I ended up eating because my boyfriend wouldn't touch them.

Why should you go here?

-Unpretentious
-Chill small cozy place for a quick bite and good conversation
-you can people watch if you get a window seat
-Good Service

Why you might not want to go here?

-There isn't a bathroom inside the restaurant so you have to get a key and go inside the building of the restaurant.
-Restaurant only has 16 seats total.
-Don't go here if you are easily claustrophobic

Overall opinion: I would definitely go back to Akiko's as I enjoy a cozy little restaurant that you wouldn't expect so close to Union Square.
author: Cellina B.

description: killer sushi. Different roles. place is beyond small with only 4 tables. Opt to sit at the sushi bar.
author: Katie E.

description: It is an unusual place. I read a couple of reviews. If my experience is radically different from others, I try to take into consideration my own frame of mind at the time. But mine is similar. The people that work there are unusual. The chef does not speak English and was a little nervous trying to answer a question. Their waiter came in and saved the day. The woman that works there is lacking finesse, but I'm telling you, go into any of the restaurants in China town as well. That charming, pampering type of service that so many of us Americans have come to enjoy and expect, not happening at a lot of restaurants there and a language barrier makes it worse. Before anyone crinkles an eyebrow, this restaurant is not in China Town. It's easy to find. It's on Mason one block west of Union Sq. Ok on to the food! Like so many other Asian restaurants here in SF when you sit down they bring you a pot of tea. I quite like that. Similar to how some restaurants will bring a glass of water. It's no charge and I really like that, especially on a day like today, rain, chilly. I had two rolls. The San Francisco which I quite liked. A basic sake maki which I liked as well. Their miso was good and the serving is generous. I ordered a combo which is reasonably priced. It also comes with a small cabbage salad. They did forget it, but brought it right out when I asked for it. They are not polished. They have been there a long time and we go every year. I can't imagine they would not let people order more food. That was a bizarre review. I can imagine that the woman that worked there came across as uncouth, and I have not enjoyed any of these tiny restaurants when they are packed and very busy. This restaurant is a good restaurant.
author: Nancy P.

description:
In the end, the coat rack hitting me on the head was sort of a highlight of my experience at Akiko's.  

After walking past this micro-sushi restaurants many times, I really wanted to like it.  It's on my way home from work, they have just 4 tables and a sushi bar, and it exuded a quaint, neighborhood-y vibe.  

But from the start, things just did not go our way.  Because it's so small, the seating process is a little...stressful.  You pop your head in the door between two tables to tell the waitress you're there...if you can get her attention.  Then if more people arrive, you're all just waiting outside unsure of what the procedure is.  I mean, it's not that complicated: when someone leaves, the next person in line goes in.  But still, it felt a bit uncomfortable that there was no process and no acknowledgement of your place in line.  But that's cool, it's a small joint so they're light on process. No biggie.

We were finally seated and I tried to be strategic and ordered a first round of food immediately: miso, edamame, some nigiri.  Figured I'd jump in to beat the other people who sat down at the same time we did.  Well, that failed miserably.  Everyone else got served at least their first course before us and when our starters eventually came out, the edamame was way overcooked and the miso was flavorless.  

Then a coat rack fell on my head.  It didn't so much fall on its own, but had help from the shopping bags some spendy Eastern European tourists had hung from its appendages.  But no harm, no foul, and the 20 people in the place all had a good laugh about it.

And then we sat, starters finished, for about 20 minutes without any food coming our way.  We watched as everyone around us was served, ate, and some left.  Finally, the waitress came over and asked us how were were doing.  Um, well, I've been considering eating the stray grains of sushi rice that fell off my table neighbor's plate, but other than that, I'm cool.  

At last, our rolls arrive, and they were fine.  We had a hamachi with green onion, the sumo roll, and the swamp roll.  None were particularly spectacular, but they weren't bad either.

The meal ended with some nice watermelon bites for dessert.  We paid our bill, and were the last ones to leave. 

I feel like I'm giving this place an outlier review as everyone around us seemed to have had a great time.  People left smiling and made a special point to thank the sushi chef.  For whatever reason, Akiko's hated us that fateful Thursday night.  And so, despite this poor experience I'm totally willing to give them another shot.  But next time, I'm wearing a helmet and packing some snacks, just in case.
author: Eric S.

description: Hubs and I accidentally ate at this Akiko's when looking for Akiko's RESTAURANT. DOH. Don't make the same mistake we did, kids. The sushi was ok and the prices were fair for Union Square. Service was efficient and friendly. Sushi craving nearly satisfied.
author: Kel S.

description: Pretty decent dinner. Nice service, pretty cheap prices for the quality of the sushi, and a great atmosphere. I had the Volcano roll and a sashimi sampler - the volcano roll was pretty good, but felt the spicy sauce overwhelmed the fish a bit in the roll. Still tasty but nothing to phone home about.
author: Dustin H.

description:
It bears repeating: not to be confused with Akiko's on Bush St.

I was in the city on business and looked up a sushi restaurant near the hotel.  I found Akiko's on Bush, but inadvertently walked to this Akiko's.  By looks alone, it certainly doesn't give me the impression of a great sushi restaurant, but, really, IT IS.  

PROS: The service was stellar.  We asked the server to bring us her favorite rolls and to keep them coming until we said stop.  She brought us some of the best sushi I've ever had.  Make sure you order the "SUMO ROLL".  By far the best roll they have.  Usually when I pull the "bring me your favorites" routine, the bill is extremely inflated, but not at Akiko's.  It was extremely reasonable for the amount of food and Sake we ordered.  The food is fresh, the service is great, the prices are reasonable.

CONS: This place is tiny.  Minuscule.  Microscopic.  One 4-top (squeezed in), three 2-tops (shoved in corners) and a three person bar (which is uncomfortably close to the 4-top).  When I was done, I asked for a restroom and the server escorted me next door to a secured apartment building, punched in the code and told me to walk downstairs.  I walked down the stairs and emerged into an apartment's laundry room.  The bathroom there made airplane bathrooms look spacious.

SUMMARY: Great food, great service, great prices.  If a table isn't available, wait for one.  Just be sure to go to the bathroom before you get there!
author: Nino F.

description: I used to come here when I worked in the area. It's a really small restaurant (everyone can basically hear your entire convo lol), but they have some pretty good sushi =) The ladies working here are super nice and the rolls are awesome and reasonably priced! I think I would order take out from here for sure!
author: Diane L.

description: Delicious food and great service. Be advised that their spicy sauce is made with habaneros and therefore is very spicy but very yummy. The sake was also fairly well priced. We just ordered the cheapest one because that was all that was available. One thing to bear in mind for this place is that it's small and fills up quick (line outside before it opens) so you should make reservations. We didn't and they graciously gave us a table anyway, but we could tell it wasn't easy for them to do so because of the reservations they already had lined up. LOVE THIS PLACE!
author: Jael J.

description: Went here a few weeks ago and the service was pretty slow, which was surprising considering there are only four tables... took a while to get place settings, ordered a beer and it didn't show up for five-ten minutes (another table ordered and was served drinks in the meantime).
author: Kevin B.

description:
Decent place for lunch. Their menu was pretty short, Nothing really stuck out so i ended up ordering the udon & sake maki....i know...maybe i didn't order the right things again, but i thought it was just okay. The food however, did take a really really long time to come out - i believe it was about 20-25 mins...my friend and i were on our hr lunch breaks so we were kinda on a time crunch :(....

Other than that, i thought the place was very cute and intimate. I'll prob come back but not for lunch since it takes a while for your food to come out.
author: Rosalynn D.

description: They have sushi on their happy hour menu, which no other places in the Union Square/Nob Hill area have (I've called the other places to ask). The sushi was decent. The restaurant is on the small side so this might not be a good place to bring a large group of people.
author: Andrew M.

description: Bad: watered down soup, cold old edamame, cozy seating for 4 groups of ppl. Good: Hana roll, service (only 4 tables to wait on so duh), frosty beer glasses, lotta pickled ginger given.
author: Kasey H.

description: This place was good until several month ago... my 2 last times there, all was so sloppy... won't go anymore, sorry
author: JB J.

description:
I won't tell the story of how I happened to walk by this place when I needed to put some food on top of the alcohol I'd already consumed but I'll happily review them.

This place is tiny, all of the windows were fogged up and I had to come in to see the menu. 

I walked up to the sushi bar and had a seat. There were three couples in the tiny place and it felt full. Either the stools were to high or the counter too low. 

The Sushi chef was female; I have no feelings either positive or negative about this but I'd never seen a female sushi chef and found it interesting.

When I eat sushi I usually order from the Sushi chef but this time the waitress interfered, this happens sometimes but the reason I prefer to order from the Chef is because the Waitress does not know what fish is the freshest.

There are four rules about authentic sushi that most people in America don't know:

1) Eat the fish from light to dark
2) Do not mix the soy sauce and the wasabe
3)  Dip the fish,and not the rice, into the soy sauce.
4) A piece of Nigiri, or a section of maki (roll), is one portion and should be taken in one bite.

The sushi was acceptable and the prices were reasonable. Both of the ladies were fairly dour and eating there felt like kind of a bummer. 

I'd eat there again if I happened to be in the 'hood but I wouldn't go out of my way.
author: Manny F.

description: Great food in a nice neighborhood. The staffs are really friendly. I love their sashimi combination. And have you tried their cabbage salad? really really nice. but I hope they  make it bigger though, they only give in a tiny dish. But I love this place anyway, very comfortable atmosphere.
author: Suabot J.

description:
For good quality sushi and a bonus cabbage salad that's complimentary, this is the place to go. The rolls are good. Salmon special and San Fransico are standouts for me. 

Good service. 

A little small but I guess that is what a sushi bar is all about. 

Not the most exotic/Americanized sushi which is what I enjoy so that is why I give it 4 stars along with the crampped spacing.
author: Lee S.

description: This was the best hole in the wall sushi place. Super cheap and super delicious. You must try the butterfish sushi! The best sushi in the city in my opinion.
author: Ben G.

description:
My favorite new place !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! The maki rolls and seaweed salad are so great ... yummy ! I'm so excited to go back soon !!! It's a tiny restaurant , the food is so fresh , the service very nice and the prices very reasonables. Highly recommended.
Thank you Akiko's !!!
author: F T.

description: Place just opens, and I am the first diner in.  The menu says the entrees come with miso and salad.  Chicken teriyaki arrives - no soup or salad.  Don't I get a soup and salad?  Oh, we're out.  You're out of miso soup and salad...hmmm...ok...can I have some wakame?  Food was mediocre, flavorless, bland.  Server then sits down at a table and starts eating his employee meal.  Huh?  They could't feed him before they opened?  Just a thought.  Meanwhile another diner walks in and felt uncomfortable asking to be seated, thinking, does he work here, or is he a diner??? No one greets her for a few uncomfortable minutes.  Sayonara, there are many more venues that don't remind me of a Jim Jarmusch film.
author: Angelo S.

description:
Pretty basic little neighborhood place.  Decent but nothing great.
The spicy dishes had too much mayo mixed in with the fish, but overall was pretty good.
Other drawback is it can be very slow.  There are only 4 tables (don't worry there was no wait when we were there), but it still took them about 20 minutes to get out a new order.
For some reason these neighborhoody places with just decent but not great food get amazing yelp reviews.  I guess everyone likes the little guy.  That's fine just don't expect anything other than pretty average stuff here - this isn't anything great.  I'd only go if I was already right there for something else.  Not worth walking more than about 2-3 blocks to get to.
author: Ric S.

description:
I'm at the point where I'm getting to know good sushi (lame qualifier: I have good friends who are sushi chefs). The pix of the rolls looked nice, but I went in to get some sashimi and... Looked at the menu and realized they are selling slices for $2 each ($20 for a 10 piece). In my opinion, that's too much for this place. Why? The sushi bar is non existent. You cannot even sit in 2 of the 5 seats because there is a table too close to the horrible barstools. And the tables? Wobble. How are we going to balance 3 beers, sake and soy sauce on a wobbly table???

And to boot, the quality is not all that. Up the street at Sanraku they were $26 for a 10 piece. So i urged my friends to leave and we went to Mikado. Mikado has a 10 piece for $15 and 7 piece for $9. Why would i pay more here???

If you're looking for excelent sushi at a fair price, go to Mikado. If you are looking to splurge go to Nihon, Sushi Groove, Tokyo a gogo, or Blowfish. If you are looking to stretch out and enjoy go anywhere but here. 

I didn't enjoy this place.
author: Adam X.

description:
We stopped in for lunch and the food was very good.  The place is rather small, non-descript and essentially a hole in the wall but the food makes up for it.
Having been to Chin's and thoroughly enjoyed our food I thought I'd visit this place since it was closer to home.
We had the following:
Spicy Scallop Roll-very good
2 SF Maki-super!
1 Shrimp & avocado maki-Very good
Our server was attentive.  I enjoyed some nice hot saki with my meal and left satisfied and content.
author: Lizete S.

description: Delicious sushi at good prices. Filled up on 3 different rolls and an order of nigiri, and 2 sakes for around $30. The rolls I had were covered in fish roe, which was very tasty and a change of pace from sushi I get in the Midwest. I sat at the bar to watch the chef make the sushi and it was entertaining, since I visited alone. The waitress was attentive and made sure my tummy was full before I left. It wasn't busy when I ate, but I was in around 6:00 on a Monday night, and I expect that it would be busier later and on prime nights. I guess there's also a larger restaurant with the same name, but this place on Mason was small and homey. A great find in Union Square.
author: Rick B.

description:
Just because a place is tiny doesn't necessarily mean I'm obligated to write a tiny review, does it? 

hmmmm...  The sushi library.  The sushi closet. 

Yes, this place is a uniquely adorable hole-in-the-wall, with its ornate crown mouldings, wasabi green walls and storefront location.  It certainly earns back a star for setting.  Its so tiny and there are so few patrons, you find yourself having to be extra hushed, literally conversing in whispers so as not to bother those around you and to keep your conversation semi-private.  And don't try to go to the restroom which is deep in the dungeon-like bowels of the neighboring building, requiring two separate keys to get into--one for the front door and one for the restroom.

The food is good; my compadre and I had the albacore sashimi, little salads, miso and edamame.  We also would have had a california roll with snowcrab (listed on the menu) instead of "krab", had the waitress understood that I wanted snowcrab (as listed on the menu), instead of fake krab, in my california roll.  Even though it was clearly listed on the menu, the waitress simply could not understand that I wanted this item substituted in my roll, neither could the sushi chef, english being their fourth or fifth language.  So I just canceled that one.  We would also have had the spicy tuna roll, the yellowtail with green onion roll and the halibut nigiri had the service not been excruciatingly slow to the point where we were forced to cancel the second part of our order in favor of punctuality to our evening merrymaking.  Before canceling the order, we made sure that the sushi chef had not yet begun to prepare the order, which she had not.  But canceling the order proved to be difficult, language barrier and all.  When the waitress finally understood that we had to cancel the second part of the order because we were in a bit of a rush, she added up our tab in a huff, punching the buttons on her calculator with surprising fury for one so diminutive and shy.  

So in summary, this is a cute, one-of-a-kind setting, but overall, a somewhat disappointing and awkward experience.
author: Rick H.

description:
This place is: 
1) tiny (4 tables)
2) slow
3) quiet
4) cheap ($5-11 per roll)

if that's what you're looking for, and sometimes I am, then this place is perfect.  The rolls we (finally) received were delicious and the little cabbage salad served for free beforehand was a nice little treat.  other than that....if you want to talk during your meal, this probably isn't the place to go (with only 4 tables the place can get pretty quiet), but if you just want straight-forward, satisfying sushi, perhaps being the only person talking in the restaurant is okay.
author: Luthien N.

description:
I went to Akiko Sushi last night after a long walk in the city.  I was starving and craving some good Japanese food.  When we walked in, I was taken aback by how small the restaurant was.  But usually in these cases, small restaurants tend to be surprisingly good.

I went to go use the bathroom which was located downstairs in the apartment building next to the restaurant.  SKETCHY.  I had to walk downstairs into a cement-floored laundry room and squeezed myself into the 1-toilet/1-sink bathroom that was about 5 feet by 3 feet

I came back and drank some tasty warm green tea and ordered the Chicken Donburi.  I would like to call this dish the Healthy Donburi.  White meat chicken (not breaded or fried) with egg, zucchini, asparagus, carrot, onion, and sauce.  Weird assortment of vegetables for donburi.  It seemed like Chinese stir fry with egg and teriyaki sauce.  Not impressed.

Not only that, the waitress wasn't very friendly and I felt like she was judging all the customers with a mean look on her face.

I would not come back to this place.  But for those who are STILL interested, stick with ordering sushi, and try to avoid the bathrooms.

On the upside.  the tea and complimentary slices of pear were delicious.
author: Melissa L.

description:
This place is TINY.  I felt like I was attending a little girl's tea party, seated on a tiny seat at a tiny table drinking from tiny cups and chatting up a stuffed bear, a Raggedy Andy, and a pony.  If I had laid down in the middle of the restaurant, I could have touched 3 of the four walls simultaneously.

After meeting up with my brother and his wife for day 2 of The Boys from Wyoming [Ben P.: continual purveyor of jokes only 5 people will fully understand], it was time for some lunch.  One of the guys from bro's squadron had a hankering for sushi (apparently, you can't get good sushi in Kuwait.  Who knew?], and had heard this was a good place, so we ambled on over.

A couple of Sapporos and lies later, we're knee-deep in a decent-sized pile of sushi, at a pretty darn reasonable price.  I also had some udon noodles, and I wouldn't recommend it.  Thankfully I had the good sense to tuck the napkin in as a bib before I tucked myself into the udon.

Sushi twice in three days is pushing it for me.  It flies in the face of my all-beef diet.  But, in life as in the law, the most important part of the rule is the exception.
author: Ben P.

description:
After researching about twenty sushi bars in the area (starving), my fiance and I finally decided on Akiko's, thank you yelpers.

Well, we made the right choice. So good! It's a good thing we went at 6pm on a Saturday though, the place is tiny! If we had gone any later we would have had to wait. There are 4 stools at the sushi bar, and then two tables of 4, and two of 2. This was a positive thing for me though, I like an intimate atmosphere where you can come back again and again and get to know the staff. (which was two women when we went, a server and a sushi chef.)

We ordered the Miso soup, (fabulous) which came with a small cabbage salad (tasty) .Then we ordered way too many maki rolls. The portions were bigger than what I'm used to. The fish was fresh and the rice perfectly cooked. Since we ordered like six rolls, they came out one or two at a time, which made us feel like we were having a six course meal or something special like that. Our favorite ended up being the sumo roll, which had perfectly cooked shrimp in it, tuna wrapped on the outside, and a yummy soy ginger sauce drzzled over it.

At the end of the meal we were presented with fresh cut watermelon and our check, which was surprising smaller than I had estimated in my head, yay! The service was quick and attentive, the atmosphere home-y and happy. This is now our regular sushi spot, end of story!
author: Stephany T.

description:
My hair colorist moved to Spain a few months back. The nerve!  I miss her desperately and can't find anyone half as talented. Why, you ask, am I bitching about my hair color problems when I'm supposed to be reviewing Akiko's? I'll tell you....Akiko's is just across the doorway. I used to look forward to a solo sushi feast and shopping spree after having my hair highlighted. Those were the days! Now, I rarely go downtown because of traffic, crowds, and parking hassles. It was worth it in the name of fabulous hair, but now....too much of a pain. I have missed Akiko's.

Like many other reviewers have said, it's great to see an all female staff (including the sushi chef). Their food has always been fresh and tasty. I especially love the San Francisco Maki (crab and spicy albacore), roasted eggplant, mixed greens, and miso marinated salmon. YUM. 

To top it all off, their prices are very reasonable and service is always friendly. It's just too bad they don't have a legit bathroom (see other reviews for details). Just hold it until you get home, or walk down to Max's on the corner. Speaking of bathrooms, I'd like to review public restrooms in the city. Now THAT would be helpful, especially with the holiday shopping madness.
author: Abby W.

description: Do not go here! I went here a while back and received the worst service.  I've never been to a restaurant where the chef told me he could get the fish I asked about by "going upstairs to his house" I suppose he keeps his fish in his upstairs home and comes "downstairs" to his restaurant to serve it????
author: Megan M.

description:
I ordered some lunch from Akiko's yesterday and it was awesome. Lizzie roll may be the only Salmon I'll ever eat again. 

Even their handrolls (a total clusterf**k at many sushi joints) were perfectly sized and constructed.
author: Jason R.

description: Best sushi in the downtown area.  I have never ordered the famous "Volcano Roll" but everything else on the menu is delicious.  If you get a chance, sit at the sushi bar and talk to the chef.  Hope you enjoy!
author: Eric H.

description:
Perfect little sushi place only a block or so from Union Square.  The vibe is as if you're in a sushi chef's kitchen - their home kitchen.  The sea green walls, the cabinets behind the sushi bar, the simple chairs and tables, etc.  A nice break from the super trendy or ultra traditional decors found in a lot of sushi places.

The miso soup ($1.50) was very flavorful and the perfect way to warm up on a cold summer night in San Francisco.  The cucumber salad ($4.50?) consisted of Jenga block-like cucumber sticks in a tasty dressing (sesame-based?) with chopped asparagus and strings of crab meat mixed throughout.  Really good.

The hamachi sashimi platter ($10) comes with 5 nice-sized chunks of deliciously buttery yellowtail.  The unagi sushi - two pieces for $3.75 - was very good as well - the BBQ glaze was more subtle (less sweet) than normal and let the freshness of the eel stand on its own.

Great suggestion SF Yelpers!
author: Scott R.

description:
I really tried to like this place. A place with 3 women, host, chef and the dish cleaning lady. Seldom see this kind of setting in any restaurants.

Walking in and was told someone reserved the table. Look, it's a tiny and local place and if people did not show up they should really reconsider their policy. So I politely waited and said I could do takeout. Someone must have heard me as they paid instantly and left.

Now I am really hungry and had almost memorized the menu before the host came to take my orders and they immediately served hot tea and cabbage. I looked at the stressed out chef with like 5 orders in front of mine. I started thinking I would starve to a dried plum before I see any food.

A couple people walked in doing takeout and the chef decided to do theirs first. The host was very embarrassed and said it should not be done that way... so they got into an argument.

So I continued to wait with my drooling and tired look. 40 minutes later my ama ebi showed up. It was very good shrimp but I was too hungry to slowly enjoy it. Another 10 minutes later my rainbow roll showed up. Rice was totally soaked with water. Fish was okay but I could see the sushi falling apart (rice was not properly prepared and not sticky enough.)

I drank too much tea at this point that I lost my appetite and had to cancel the last order. They were definitely not happy about it.

Well, $15 dollars for this, I would rather go somewhere else.
author: T L.

description: So this sushi restaurant is only half a block away from the JW Marriott, where I was staying, so I decided to give it a try. This is definitely a hole in the wall, so seating is very limited. I sat at the bar because I figured I didn't want to take up one of the four tables in the place. I ordered salmon and albacore sushi and a spider roll. The salmon was ok but the albacore tasted so weird. I'm not sure if it was due to the sushi not being fresh but it left a bad taste in my mouth. The spider roll was just ok, nothing special. I was really hoping the sushi would be great but I was disappointed. The service was just ok as well. I noticed someone from the kitchen staring at me strangely. I don't know what that was about... I would say, skip this place... The prices were fine but I'm sure there are better places in SF.
author: Beldevina P.

description:
Wow is this place small. The sushi was reasonably priced and yummy.  I don't get much variety outside the spicy tuna.  

Only negative was the bathroom was located in the basement of an apartment complex.  When I finally got to the bathroom, there was no toilet paper!   It only made this player even cooler and more hardcore.
author: Dan B.

description:
Ok...they're batting about .500 at best...the first time my wife and I went was at around 2PM and the place was empty, as it was after lunch hour, and they close from 3-5PM.

The food and service were pretty good, but, again, we were the only patrons.

I went back by myself this evening at around 6PM, and it was about 2/3 full.  I ordered a Rainbow roll, tuna roll and salmon skin hand roll.  I knew what I wanted, and ordered as soon as I sat down.  This is important, as will be made clear.

All arrived within a reasonable amount of time...except for the salmon skin hand roll.

A part y of two arrived 20 minutes after I did, and received their order rather quickly, including a salmon skin hand roll.

I asked where mine was, and the waitress said, "It's almost ready."  Fine.  Ten minutes later, I called her over and asked her where it was.

She said it takes 15 minutes to prepare.  Fine.

Five minutes later, I asked her where it was.  She said it's done, and I'll get it right now. Fine.

Five minutes after that, I told her to cancel it, as I was done with them...I suspect that my roll was given to the diners at the adjacent table, which I would have understood if she had just admitted the error (maybe the order wasn't put in...I don't know).

When I told her that I wanted to cancel the order, she said, "Can't you wait just another two or three minutes?" which was interesting, in that she had previously told me that it was done, and she was going to bring it to me.

Now I fully realize that she was not responsible for preparing the food, but it doesn't take a half hour to make a salmon skin hand roll, and I was so aggravated by the whole fiasco that my meal was ruined.

It was by no means sushi to die for, and the service and attention to detail were absolutely awful.

By the way, the waiter who took care of us when we first went there said that the sushi chef and cook are Chinese, not Japanese.

Akiko's Sushi Bar gives new meaning to the word "Meh."

THIS REVIEW IS BY Richard L., not ANIL.
author: Anil H.

description:
Was in the neighborhood and hungry... Stopped in here for a few pieces of nigiri and a hand roll... this place is SUPER tiny... only seats 12 at tables and 3 at the sushi bar... not japanese owned... 

decent selection of rolls and sashimi, but nothing crazy... spicy sauce tastes really weird... I'd skip the spicy sauce if I were you... normal prices... ok service... i wouldn't go out of my way to come here, but if you are in the area, why not...
author: Jen D.

description:
Went on a cold Wednesday night to sit at the sushi bar alone for a quick bite.. WRONG! This place is tiny.. which is ok until you are stuck sitting alone next to an annoying talkative European tourist for an hour and a half. No kidding.. I order a sashimi sampler and a roll and it took an hour to get them both. 

Sittting at the sushi bar made me not want to eat, seriously. I question the cleanliness of this place after watching the sushi chef wipe plates down with the same rag she wiped off the squid covered cutting board. Also never saw her wash her hands! Even after watching this slow older woman take an hour to make about 10 rolls total, I still somewhat enjoyed my sushi. Maybe I was just starving at that point?

I would say skip the place and go somewhere else.. I will next time
author: Sarah W.

description:
4.5.  Personally, I realllly liked this place.  It might have to do with the fact that I ate here after a full day of wandering all around San Francisco with my best friend and absolutely no map and having only been a few times when I was younger.  It was an interesting day to say the least.  So I was starvvvvving, and ended up having to walk about 15 minutes to get here after walking around and taking random busses and the bart everywhere all day long. Not to mention, I had been looking forward to sushi the whole day and it was about 10:00 already.  So maybe i'm a little biased because I probably would have enjoyed almost anything at that point. 

But really though, it was good quality sushi.  I got some roll.. I forgot what it was called but I think it was maybe a veggie roll or something with super fresh salmon on the outside that had lemon smothered all over it.  I love lemon. And fresh salmon. So I was very pleased. And to be honest, I still crave that roll everytime I get sushi.  I have no clue what my friend got but she enjoyed it as well. The sushi chef was really nice too, which always adds to the experience.  Yeah, it's a bit tiny but I thought it was cute. But then, once again, I came at 10:00 at night so it wasn't exactly crowded.
In conclusion, it was pretty great for the price.  You should probably try to come at an off hour to avoid being cramped in there. But definitely give it a try. :)
author: Kim S.

description:
Last visit, bout 4 years ago.

Kinda borderline expensive. 

Food is decent. 

I just like their combination lunch specials. 

Is it this place or does everyone get diarrhea when you eat raw fish?

Whenever I get a stomach ache from a sushi restaurant I stop going in. So, you better stop selling expired stuff.
author: Keit K.

description: So good! Looks really sketchy because it's real small but it's really good! It's a nice intimate sushi bar with only 4 tables and 4 seats at the bar. The sushi was awesome and the sashimi was just as good! Great prices too! If your in the mood for sushi and want something quick and easy go here!
author: Lauren W.

description:
This place is amazing.  I loved the spider Roll and the California Maki and Spicy Tuna Maki were delicous.  In fact every roll we had we loved but definetely get the spider roll.  Prices are reasonable.  Great sushi and a hidden gem downtown or Union square area for Sushi.roll. 

2nd time -  The place is small and if it is packed beware you may wait over 45 minutes for your food.  It is very good though.  The only bad thing is they ran out of a roll I really wanted and neglected to tell me until they did my other roll after waiting for 45 minutes when I went for dinner and only ordered two rolls.
author: Harry E.

description:
We sat at the bar excited to try a different small sushi place (small generally means good in our eyes). The fish looked shockingly bad so we opted for the udon (my boyfriend chose vegetarian, I chose chicken). Avoid this place. I could taste the MSG. Gross! The chicken was like that chicken out of a can - mostly fat, undercooked, bland, and unappetizing.

The service was very slow (they couldn't handle four tables?? Seriously?) and I wouldn't call it friendly. There are any number of better sushi places in the neighborhood and definitely in the city. I will not be back here.

I try to avoid generalizing and give people the benefit of the doubt, but in this case it was another case of non-Japanese people making bad Japanese food.
author: Shawna S.

description: I was wandering the streets and stumbled upon this adorable little sushi joint that only has 3 tables! The host was incredibly nice and had the sushi chef make me several half rolls so I could sample everything. The food and saki were amazing as well as the people. So happy I found this place!
author: Holly L.

description:
