I enjoy the small places, knowing full well that usually means competing for the limited space at these places. Akiko's was no different, me and my friend were able to score a table relatively easily, but people coming in and out throughout the night were forced to wait.

The first thing that hit me when I came in was the extreme humidity going on in the place. You get used to it, but it's quite a hit to the face after walking around a cool SF night.

That night there was only one sushi chef working behind the counter, which I feel is the usual case. So you're going to have wait a long time for your order to come out as that one lone chef is inevitably overworked. Again, this is something you have to expect with a small place. 

Unfortunately I didn't feel like the sushi I got that night was worth the wait. The rice didn't taste all that fresh nor did the fish amaze me either way. Maybe again, it's because the place was so humid that the fish and rice tasted a bit average, but in any case, I was disappointed with what I got after having to wait so long for the order to get sent out. Definitely okay sushi, but not worth the time it took.
author: Roland C.

description:
Came here for the reception following the premiere of 'Falling for Grace' and only had the appetizers, most were amazing and had so much flavor. And yes, it's as small as everyone here states.
I will come back to check out the Sushi again.
author: Arlene C.

description: Small intimate setting. San Francisco roll is great. Good sushi!
author: Jeff C.

description:
So before coming to SF, I made a list of restaurants to try using the reviews here on Yelp.  It hasn't failed me in the past but must admit, this one did.

I'm from Toronto and though we aren't known for the greatest/freshest sushi anywhere, it's still pretty darn good.  I've been told by many that the sushi in SF is very fresh and figured I'd use Yelp to help me find a good one within walking distance to my hotel so I decided to try this restaurant.  I won't comment on the establishment itself 'cuz good food will always trump in my book.

To start, I ordered a Hamachi sashimi appetizer for $10.  It only came with 5 medium size pieces.  It did taste fresh but wasn't anything out of the ordinary.  I had the spicy tuna chef's special ($8.95) to follow which came with 4 pieces of spicy tuna maki, 2 salmon nigiri and 2 BBQ eel nigiri.  It was over in about 2 minutes and I was wondering when the main course would come out.

For the price, it really wasn't too bad.  But the 2 star rating description sums it all up, "Meh.  I've experienced better."

Now off to get a slice of pizza...
author: Michael L.

description:
This is one of the smallest restaurants that I have been to in a long time.  
A word to the wise, if you want to order to go, if they say 15 minutes, add on an extra 37.  
The sushi is WONDERFUL, the service is good, all the sushi is yummy yummy to die for.  The seaweed salad is excellent, as was the dragon roll that I had.  Definately worth going to.
author: Janet R.

description: Good, but be prepared to wait!  Even after you wait for a table it took a long time (45 minutes) for the sushi to be served.  Appetizers came right away, but the sushi chefs just couldn't keep up with the orders.
author: Mike J.

description:
I really like the sushi here.  The fish has always been super fresh, and everything I've tried there has been good. There are no tempura rolls on the menu, which makes me sad, but if you're in the mood for fresh fish it's perfect. It's a small place, and it's not a place to go if you're in a hurry. 

Sushi's a hard thing to rate because everyone wants something different from a sushi restaurant. Personally I like that it's small and don't mind waiting a while as long as it's fresh. This is a place you come for the basics. The maguro is good, the avocado roll is really good, but be prepared to wait a while.

FYI: Try the yellowtail special roll... seriously worth it.
author: Sara G.

description:
One of the consequences of my job is that I've developed an acute sensitivity to light and color.  

The joint was lit with a single light in the middle of the room, and one or two other lights elsewhere.  Coupled with the cramped seating and the size of the place, I felt like I was eating in a sushi bar perfect for a hobbit.

Despite that, the Chinese owned sushi dispensary wasn't so bad. We had the sashimi platter, dragon and scallop rolls.  The dishes didn't feel like they were processed by a machine. It really felt like each piece was put together by my Japanese mom.  Well, ok, I'm not Japanese, but that's the way I would imagine my mom to do for me if she was.

Four stars if there was better lighting and a bathroom that didn't feel like it was located in the dungeon--which it was.
author: Alfred Y.

description:
This sushi place has gotten me through my first year of college, and despite the many times I've gone there, I've never tired of it. 
I love the small atmosphere.
I love the constant refills on hot tea.
I love the fresh ingredients.
I love the fact that there's a female sushi chef (a rarity in this city!).
I love the small cabbage salad that comes before each meal.
I love the orange slices with toothpicks served at the end while we divvy up the bill.
AND I love that the ladies there recognize me and my friend every time we return.
author: lizzie r.

description: Unfriendly. Poor customer service. Small rolls with minimal amounts of fish. Small, cozy atmosphere though. The young female employee was unfriendly, business-like, and did not even smile or say hello. I ordered the Disco roll which had "spicy tuna and eel". I had 2 pieces and did not taste or see the tuna. The employee tried to show me minuscule ground-shredded tuna in the roll, and stated none of their rolls had actual pieces of fish. I had never experienced this before. I returned the roll and offered to pay for half the cost. She said there was no way to do that and brought me the full bill. After discussion, she finally did not charge me. I left some cash to cover the cost of the 2 pieces I had. There are too many other incredible sushi and other restaurants in SF, with good customer service. I thought I would try something new, but will never come here again.
author: S C.

description:
A nice little sushi bar that we happened on.  Food was well prepared.  The menu was a bit limited as they must not have a deep fryer.

Nothing great....but not bad either.  3 stars.
author: Brian M.

description:
Have you ever seen women sushi chefs?  Me either!  I was searching for a place to grab lunch on a Saturday and wandered two blocks from work to this little spot.  It's a bit of a hole in the wall, which I tend to love.  I ordered a Caterpillar roll to go.  It was decently priced and service was great - meaning, I sat at the bar watching the lady sushi chef make my food right then and there.  

I've had mediocre sushi before, so I didn't get my hopes up with this place.  I was prepared to bite into a blah piece of sushi; however, it was yummy!  The rice was soft, avocado was on point, and the unagi was delicious.  Don't get me wrong, I've had better Caterpillar rolls else where, but this place was pretty darn good.  It wasn't THE best, but it hit the spot.
author: Lynda N.

description:
Auper cute little sushi restaurant! My new favorite sushi places dfowntown.  Excellent rolls that are HUGE and a very good value.

Try the swamp roll.
author: lisa g.

description:
Akiko's is a small little spot, there is literally only about 4 tables, and a mini sushi bar. A good place to get some food for your lunch break. 

The sushi was decent, but not amazing. I have definitely eatten at better places, but for a small mom and pop restaurant...it's not too bad. 
Despite the mediocre food, the service wasn't bad at all and if you can't think of any other place to get some Japanese food for your lunch break.
author: Catherine O.

description:
One of my favorite sushi places. 

The interior design while indeed tiny is also very modern and clean (think IKEA) instead of some japanese version of a chili's restuarant where gravity and "ancient" artifacts threaten your shoyu dish. Sorry, I just mean that this place is really clean and nice and a good break from Union Square and Chinatown. 

Also, don't try to order in Japanese! These women (and especially my favorite chef) are Chinese. 

Meals often include a perfect little salad and an ending piece of fruit, sliced and served with a toothpick. And a very reasonable bill.
author: Alex M.

description: My friend and I were in mood for sushi and we spotted Akiko's Sushi then we walked up there. The space was tiny...can only seat up to 15 people. We both ordered the sashimi plate. Sashimi quality was alright. Seaweed salad was pretty decent. We ordered mochi for dessert and we wouldn't recommend mochi. First, mochi was kinda still frozen and not tasty. Bland flavor.
author: Melody S.

description: Came here for lunch and was surprised by the awesome interior décor. Had an old Japanese temple-like feel....complete with stone walls and antique accents. Ordered TONS of rolls to share...volcano, firecracker, caterpillar, rock n roll, dragon, rainbow... along with seaweed salad and miso soup. I was a bit disappointed they did not have toro that day, but everything we did order ended up being fresh, delicious, and perfectly balanced. Great little sushi bar with amazing ambiance.
author: Vivian D.

description:
Price: cheap ($)

Quality of food: below average.  Rice fall apart easily.   I know good sushi shouldn't be like this (2 stars out of 5)

Taste: below average (2 stars out of 5)

Service: average (3 stars out of 5)

Ambience: hole in a wall type of place (1 star out of 5) 

Well, for the price I pay, I think it's still worth it.  I live nearby so this is one convenient place where I can get some sushi when I crave for it.  It's still better than the sushi you can get at safeway.  But I don't think I will go again.  If I pay a little bit more and have a little bit more time, I can get much better food at Sushi man on Bush.  

In sum, not recommended unless you live nearby.
author: Karen A.

description: What a gem! Awesome place that you will feel psyched you found. It's not high end, but very high quality. The albacore is the best I've ever had anywhere, at any price. The appetizer salads were great. The salmon skin hand roll was also special. And overall, it's just a fun off the beaten path vibe. And the prices are insanely reasonable!
author: Dino R.

description:
really fresh, inexpensive sushi. the sushi combo is a great deal, can't beat the prices. daily happy hour specials are also a BIG plus (cheap sake, beer and snack specials).

only downside is that our server wasn't very attentive and the place is tiny so getting a table can sometimes be an issue, but overall food is good and really inexpensive!
author: Jae C.

description: Pretty damn good sushi I must say. A little over priced on specialty items like uni from Japan & chu toro. Uni from Santa Barbara was decent price. There are a lot of great priced items. The long hair sushi chef was great. He recommended a lot of pieces I would not normally order. Oh and the entire staff was quick to refill our drink or clear up the ones we were done with. We had 3 different people who looked like waitress, hostess, & busser working as a great and effective team.
author: Madeline W.

description: We were seeking a casual lunch spot before a workshop at the JW so we checked this small hole-in-the-wall find through Yelp. The dragon roll was a good size for $11 but was unimpressed. The shrimp tempura was soggy and the eel didn't seem very fresh. My friend's donburi bowl was mediocre. Seek your sushi fill at other places in the surrounding area for the price you pay for here.
author: Carmina B.

description:
Teeny tiny place; not really so good for a party of more than 4.

The salmon nigiri, lizzy roll, the yellowtail, and spicy scallop were all fresh and sooooo good! 
The rolls were cut into 8 pieces each, good for our group of 3. 
Some places serve edamame hot, some cold. Akiko serves theirs cold.
The rolls were served one at a time, which I liked. It felt like we had time to sit, talk and enjoy and appreciate each of the roll's unique flavor. The best one was the Lizzy Roll which came last. It has salmon on the inside and it's topped with a lemon slice on the outside.  

Minus 1 star: 
The Spider Roll didn't have much spider to it. It didn't have the trademark fried spidery leg looking pieces sticking out. It was mostly rice, not enough crab. Not worth getting. 

I would definitely go back if I was in the neighborhood.
Yum!
author: Amy J.

description:
Granted the Japanese are into very tight and small locations...As an American, I am not into very tight and small locations. It was hard to sit my fat ass on one of their bench seats by the window. My back kept hitting against the photo hanging from the ceiling. The other side of the table was directly half way through the doorway. It was hard for people to come in and out of the restaurant. Needless to say, this place is small! It holds four tables.

I had the veggie udon which was about $6.75. It had loads of veggies inside. When I asked for the Japanese chili powder, they didn't have it.  I also had a hand roll and a spicy scallop roll. The fish was fresh and the rolls were a very decent price.

If I came here again, I'd get an order to go and eat in the privacy of my home where my couch is large enough to deal with my fat ass.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
I literally stumbled upon Akiko's walking out of my hotel room.  Oddly, it was the Blue Moon sign in the window that got my girlfriends attention, but we found that it was in fact an add for the bar behind it.  I enjoyed a Sapporo despite the fact, and we were treated to a great, friendly, and low key night of sushi.  

The place is TINY.  5 or 6 seats at the sushi bar and 5-6 tables, and that's it.  If anymore than ten people were here I would be uncomfortable.  But on our occasion, there was one man at the bar, and we were later joined by another lone diner.  

The sushi chef was a middle aged and exceptionally friendly guy, although a little difficult to understand.  I still don't know what the name of the fish was that he let me sample, but it was as good as he said it would be.  The Tuna nigiri was good, as well as the salmon, but the albacore was amazing.  Honestly the best I've ever had.  t was so soft and buttery, it literally melted in my mouth.  We also had a dragon roll which looked great and tasted good as well.  When my date asked if the chef could add some cucumber to a green salad, he happily obliged and also added asparagus and a great vinaigrette for no charge.  

The small size of the place allowed us to talk to our chef as well as the other diners.  A nice, affordable change form the crowded and cramped sushi spots I usually have to frequent.  Overall, I loved Akiko's but could understand that lunch time could be a bit packed and uncomfortable.
author: Nick H.

description: After reading the reviews, I went here last night but they were closed. Sign on the window said the water heater broke and they will open when they get it fixed. Oh well, next time.
author: Brian T.

description:
I stumbled across this place while wandering around the city.  I just moved here a week ago and had no idea what was good and what wasn't.  Thankfully, with some help from Yelp, I decided to give it a try.  

This is the perfect tiny sushi place.  It has maybe 3-4 tables and a 4-stool sushi bar, so try and show up when it might not be terribly busy.  The sushi is amazing.  It was very fresh and very well presented.  I had a ginger salad, a miso soup, and a combination of sushi that included 6 pieces of nigiri and a spicy tuna roll.  

The service was quite excellent as well.  Even though I ate alone and the chef was rather busy to talk, I never felt like there was an awkward gap where I was just sitting there.  My salad was immediately replaced with miso soup once I had finished.  My sushi arrived shortly before I finished the soup.  The check found its way over to me right as I was finishing the last piece of sushi.  Nothing was rushed, but it felt very convenient.  

The only complaint I had is that my full credit card details appeared on the merchant receipt that I was signing.  Not cool.  I asked the waitress if I could black out the first 12 digits of my card number and she agreed.
author: Christopher Z.

description:
Akiko's absolutely rocks when it comes to Sushi!  I've even taken pictures of the incredible artistic creations my favorite Sushi Chef has made me...in fact, I've even taken pictures of him!  He's the best!

You will not find better Sushi anywhere on the planet.  If you don't know what to order, just ask him what's fresh...he's always inspired by what's best!
author: Kristy T.

description: Quant little  place! Amazing sushi. We actually had reservations at the other Akikos. And mistakenly ended up at this one. What a difference of the two this one turned out to be.  (We actually went to the other one the next night-that review will be left on their link) Very sweet wait staff and yummy food.  The BEST! Would highly recommend.
author: Stephanie C.

description:
Akiko's Sushi Bar is tiny, pretty cheap and the sushi is generally fresh.  I estimated from the floor tiles that the dining space is about 100 square feet.  

I got a combo with a spicy tuna roll (4 pieces), salmon nigiri (2 pieces) and unagi nigiri (2 pieces) for $8.50.  I also got the yellowtail special roll, which is a spicy yellowtail roll topped with yellowtail (8 pieces) for $11.00.  The tea was free, and my bill (with tip) was $24.00.

I thought the service was a little slow, especially considering there was only one other person in the place.  Also, the sushi is not the most aesthetically superior and I thought there was too much rice with the nigiri, though the portions of salmon and eel were good.

Probably not a good date place.  Not romantic at all.  Also the selection of sushi, sashimi, etc. is not very extensive.  Good basic sushi at a good price.
author: John T.

description: Real hole in a wall, in every sense of the phrase, but the sushi is good and the price is fair. You won't come here for the ambiance and decorations, but you'll return for the taste and the value.
author: Anthony W.

description: I went to this tiny place for dinner once by myself when I was traveling for work.  The sushi was fantastic and there was one roll that was so amazing that I've never found anywhere else.  I live across the country but next time I'm in the area I will be back.  More places should use lemon in their specialty rolls - yum!
author: Misty L.

description: You won't regret dining at this tiny sushi bar. It's good-quality fish, expertly prepared, and the prices on happy hour specials let you enjoy lots of side dishes as well. I particularly recommend the spicy tuna roll! Also, a big cheer for the Akiko staff -- I left a valuable item behind after a late dinner, and they carefully packed it up and had it ready for me when I stopped by the next morning. Wonderful food, wonderful people.
author: Karen A.

description: I've had lunch here twice, and neither visit was great.  Service was mediocre at best.  The atmosphere chilly (maybe because of the door being so close).  The seaweed salad came from a pre-pared box.  The miso soup needed to be reheated before it was served to me (so when was it made?).  The quantity of fish in the Philly role was the smallest I've had.  I wanted to like this joint, but I'm done trying.
author: Scott M.

description:
Great spider roll and perfect nigiri. Very clean and good service.


Shatagi tod you
author: Njon W.

description:
One of the hardest things about eating out in SF is that I feel like I'm going to the opera instead of to chow down. I rarely need lighting, scenery or even a good tenor in order to enjoy my meal. And the tourist traps make me crazy. So thank you, SF Yelpers, for showing me the way to Akiko's. This tiny restaurant has some of the freshest sushi I've ever tasted. I could eat the Yellowtail special every day. I greatly enjoyed my banter with the waiter, eavesdropping on the conversations at the other three tables, and complimenting the wonderfully creative (female!) sushi chefs. 

All this, and walking distance from Union Square, place I usually have a hard time finding good, unassuming eats in.
author: Toni P.

description:
Indeed a very tiny place, but the selection is quite large. 

They have a lot of different kinds of things on their menu to chose from! Including a d'lish unagi salad and unique rolls. For such a small place, it has very unique rolls and a very creative menu. 

Once they little ladies see you in there more than once, they definitely warm up to you. =]
author: Aromy X.

description: UPDATE:  I recently went back and was served some of the worst sushi I have ever had - the fish was way too mushy and kind of made your stomach turn.  We didn't even finish it all (which is unheard of with me and sushi!).  Even their miso soup was bad; it was just totally bland.  Bummer.  I used to like this place.  Still cheap though!
author: Kerry L.

description: I forgot to review this little place. Some of the best sushi I have had in downtown. It is one of those places that you would naturally just walk by without noticing. Very small inside (only a handful of tables). The sushi was delicious. I had an assortment of rolls and sashimi that was fresh and tasty. This is my fav sushi spot in the neighborhood.
author: Brian R.

description:
Love it for well-prepared basic sushi.  It is what it is, small, clean, basic, inexpensive, good quality...miso soup, California roll, and chicken for $8.00. Or go wild with a roll special for under $10.00

If you want amazing blue fin, go to Ryoko's.  If you want good service in a neighborhoody joint, choose Akiko's.
author: Nathan W.

description:
With good timing you can claim one of 5 tables, and your stomach will feel very lucky.

Come here for low frills, fresh sushi. We ordered the unagi salad and several maki rolls, making lots of yummy noises over the course of dinner. The real standout was the swamp roll - spicy tuna and seaweed salad, the flavors and textures made for a delicious bite that we kept talking about well after we left!
author: Jen S.

description:
Although not the best sushi place I've ever been to, it is probably one of the quaintest and definitely the smallest.

Like the restaurant, simplicity is the key. The menu is simply the standard temikos, nigiris and makis, with a handful of appetizers, all at standard (read: sushi bills can add up, but there's no major sticker shock).

Yet, despite it's small stature, it seems to have a loyal following: Every sit was filled (although that wasn't too hard to accomplish), and the stream of to-go orders was every bit as consistent.

Likewise, a small restaurant has a small staff...which means it takes a while for the food to come. But with a nice seat by the window, looking out at the comings and goings of my neighborhood, I didn't mind one bit. And when the food came, I found it was definitely worth the wait.
author: Derek R.

description:
All of the European tourists seem to have Akiko's on their lists when shopping around Union Square. It does make sense though, considering Akiko is a very nice lady who makes some very delicious sushi. I would even say that Akiko's is actually one of the better places to get sushi in the city, even if it can only seat about 15 people at a time. Prices are good, and when combined with its proximity to Union Square it's a great spot to enjoy some lunch when spending the day shopping.

Give Akiko's Sushi Bar a try, it certainly left me satisfied.
author: Aaron J.

description:
If you work around Union Square, this tiny, squeaky-clean little hole in the wall is perfect to hide from the enemy (a.k.a. tourists). While they line up around the block to get into Sears or Scala for mediocre, over-prized food, one can almost always walk into Akiko and get a seat at one of the four tiny tables.

The sushi is an excellent value for what you pay. Nothing really orgasmic or out-of-this-world, but very tasty, scrumptious and cheap.

The service is always very friendly, and Vincent is simply a doll. And so I join the rank of all the other Off-Geary theatre workers in proclaiming that Akiko is THE place to go for Sushi in the Union Square district.
author: Tatjana G.

description:
Good (though perhaps not great) sushi. Friendly guy who runs (maybe owns?) the place. Reasonable prices.

I like Akiko. You will too.
author: Jeffrey F.

description:
This is a reeeally tiny, cute sushi place. My boyfriend and I were craving sushi at 9:30 on a Weds night and happened to walk by Akiko's and stop in. We ordered a few different maki rolls, and were served literally within minutes. Maybe it's because there was only 1 other person in there, but on top of the fast service the rolls were great! 

I don't know what a few of the other people were saying about the fish being gross (maybe they went on an off day? rumor has it it's bad to order fish on a Sunday because it's least fresh...). The fish in our sushi was great, and the rolls tasted great. It seemed like they added some sweet sauce to them or something. 

Definitely worth stopping in if you're in the area! Plus very decent prices!
author: Tali L.

description: It is a little scary walking in, with only 5 tables.  The waitress didn't speak very good English but was very attentive to us.  FANTASTIC sushi, the group got several rolls and sashimi and it was all amazing.  Will definitely go back next time I am in town!
author: Jeni T.

description: Terrible!  I ordered the spider roll which was supposed to have soft shell crab and it barely had any.  They cut their rolls really thick and its really hard to eat when it is basically just seaweed wrap, rice and tiny tiny bits of avocado and crab.  I also had the vegetable udon noodles and the vegetables were not fresh.  The broccoli was yellow!  I couldn't eat it!
author: Thao H.

description: No-frill sushi bar, limited seating, you can say it is literally a hole in wall. But very reasonably priced, rolls are smaller in size as compared to other places I have been to, but quantity & quality that comes in combo is more than sufficient. All in all a good place.
author: Sean S.

description: OMG. The waiters who work there are soooo hot. Remind me of the glory days in the Castro. Fresh yummy fish too.
author: Alvin W.

description: Came here because we were in a hurry to attend Nightlife at the California Academy of Science, craved sushi and decided to drop by.  First ominous sign: amazingly SMALL! Able to accommodate less than 15 people in their small restaurant bar without starting to feel claustraphobic.  The waitress wasn't all too friendly either, and didn't even automatically serve us wasabi and tea.  I don't know if I'm setting my standards high, but every sushi bar in HI automatically has tea, wasabi & soy sauce! Hmm. Well I ordered the vegetable udon since it was a cold evening and was craving something soothing.  I was SUPER hungry too.  BIG MISTAKE! The soup base was the most BLAND taste I've EVER HAD with udon noodles.  Let me talk about the udon noodles! Tasted like something that was freeze dried and reheated... NOTHING compared to HI's udon noodles, which should normally be chewy, thick and flavorful.  These udon noodles tasted like Top Ramen (Only I think even Top Ramen tastes wayYYy better then this soup).  And the tofu came in small dime-sized pieces... I was expecting WAY more then that. BOO.  I would totally rant about how HORRIBLE this place was.  NEVER again.
author: Chelsea G.

description: This place only has 3 tables and a few seats at the bar. It is so worth the wait!!! The sushi is fresh and made with love. The absolute best roll is the Sumo Roll. Shrimp in the middle and tuna on top, along with an amazing garlic and lemon sauce. Too bad I had share this role with my friends. I definitely could have gobbled this one down all by myself. The Cucumber, asparagus, and crab salad is great too! A little hot sake to top it all off and you have yourself a great meal. Oh yea, and it's CHEAP!
author: Casi C.

description: Rice was not fresh and they did not have amaebi head.  Atmosphere and service was fine.
author: Thomas L.

description:
Not to be confused with Akiko's at 431 Bush, this sushi was servicable at best IMHO. I was walking past and thought that the "other" Akiko's (which has been there for decades) might have started up a second location. I got my order to go and experienced decent but hardly exraordinary rolls. A far cry from the "other" Akiko's. 

During my next visit to 431 Bush, I inquired about their new location. "What new location?" he asked. Apparantly there is no connection. 

I wonder if the chef here is a disgruntled former employee or something.
author: J. W.

description:
I use to go here often as a college student living in the city.

I usually don't care that much about the atmosphere of a restaurant.  For me, it's mostly about the food.  However, I do feel claustrophobic here sometimes.  

The workers here aren't Japanese--nothing unusual these days.  That doesn't matter to me either as long as they know what they're doing.

The fish here is excellent for the price.  Very fresh.  But the way the nigiri is constructed falls apart easily and it's a bit heavy on the rice side.  I've never regret going here though; compared to most sushi joints, it's such a value.

I really like the cabbage salad as other reviews have mentioned.  Would love to be able to sprinkle the seasonings it comes with more liberally though.  As for side dishes I've tried the eggplant and the seaweed salad.  Both are excellent, but I highly recommend the eggplant.

It's a good place if you need your sushi fix and don't want to feel guilty spending a small fortune.
author: Du D.

description: This restaurant is perfect. The food and beer was top of the line for a good price. Although there were only 4 tables, we got in on a Saturday night in just a few minutes.  There was only one server, but she did a great job,
author: Mary Jane S.

description: I am scared to write this review for two reason. First that these ladies making sushi are actually Chinese dimsum ladies. The second reason is that its AMAZING. Holly fucking sushi hole. This place is tasty, small, and slow, but great sushi and its cheap! I had 2 cones, 1 roll, and a large beer for $16. Please note there are about 10 international hostels near by so you might just find yourself in the company of a group of cute foreign chicks.
author: Spoke K.

description:
SUSHI! It's the best thing in the world. Akiko's is this little hole in the wall place on Mason. Besides the amusing views of the Club One across the street, they serve a really really good roll. Super fresh fish, sweet service staff. Not extravagant, but if you're looking for a place to have a quite little bite to satisfy your sushi craving, this is the place to be. They don't have a huge selection of sake, but... as far as the basics go, this is the place to be...

definitely try the ahi tuna spring rolls.

if you don't, i'll come after you with a big stick. it's the best thing on the menu.
author: noelle m.

description:
We came here because it was the closest sushi place to where we were and it had some good reviews. Its definitely clean, but its SO small. Its great for like a date or crowds of 2-3 people. The decorations pretty cool- the front is all Asian-y while the back sitting area feels like your in an old English castle, dimly lit n all.. sounds weird when I say it, but its nice. 

Only con is that they don't have that much of a selection of sushi. I really like fried rolls, and they only had one. Otherwise, its not so bad!
author: Miz R.

description: Yum!!! The San Francisco Maki is my new favorite: spicy tuna and crab! Not too expensive and delicious. The space is pretty small but the food is worth the cramped location. On my way there now!!
author: Angelic S.

description: This place is great - the sushi was fresh and tasty.  The entrees are good too.  This would have been a five star review but it is kinda small.  This is one of those places where if you go and it's busy then waiting doesn't make sense because there's no where to sit and wait.  This is a must try for Japanese food enthusiasts or for anyone looking for fresh tasting and good quality fish.
author: Sal T.

description: If shopping around Union Sq., this is the place for refreshing sushi meal.  Our first lunch in SF and it's a hit.  Don't let the dour chef put you off (my enthusiastic "domo arrigato" did not melt her).  The 7-piece special with miso is tasty and good value (certainly by Irish standards) at under $10.  We ate just before 3pm, when the place was nearly empty, so no fuss over the lack of tables.
author: Brendan S.

description:
Couldn't make it at New Year Eve in the City instead staying over 3rd, Saturday;  after serious shopping & happy hour & wine
tasting at the hotel, gf said let's try out Akiko, arrived @around
7pm, since it's small, place was full, sat in front of bar, Chinese
old lady was making sushi!!!And she was buried with maybe
6/7 tickets! Ordered large sake, salmon, maguro, hamachi &
tekka maki just to try out, about 20 min later she served in a plain greenish ceramic. My Japanese gf was not impressed, so am I considered I had owned a Japanese/Fusion Sushi
bar for over a dozen years!!! She sworn she'll never go back
Akiko, period!!! I said Yup!
am I
author: PK W.

description:
Worst restaurant experience ever.

First you get there, and it's a tiny place (which would be fine) except one of the seats, which was the one we were seated at, is literally about 6 inches from the door. This means anyone that wants to come in has to squeeze around me. Next we order edamame, tea and seaweed salad. The edamame is mushy and flavorless, we couldn't get past our first pod. The tea was borderline cold. The seaweed salad wasn't bad. 

We like to order a few rolls at a time, and keep ordering until we are full, so we ordered 2. Then we waited. and waited. and waited. About an hour later I asked for the check, she said she was "just starting on my rolls". I said no way, I wanted the check for what I was served, then I paid and left.

I would never come back here again.
author: Robert B.

description:
Came here with a friend while we were on vacation. We read the reviews on Yelp and the location was convenient to where we had plans.

I didn't mind the slow service so much as I minded the fact that our food came out at completely different times. My food came out a half hour after my friend's. I have no idea why it took as long as it did, given that it's a tiny restaurant, it was a Monday, there were only a handful of people there, and our orders were small.

The food was mediocre, and the service was bizarre. At one point I worried they had simply forgotten my order.

I wouldn't recommend this place.
author: R M.

description:
Sure, it's a minuscule place with a grand total of 12 chairs, 16 if you count the bar, and you'd probably walk right by it everyday without knowing it's there.  But you owe it to yourself to discover it.  Yummy, fresh ingredients, wonderful balance in the rice (not too much or too little vinegar) make for a fabulous nigiri.  

This is not a frilly, fru-fru sushi place.  You come here for simple, easy, and excellent sushi.  None of these funky, nouveau-rolls dripping in sauce.  The edemame was a bit over done, but not badly and it seemed to be a one-off thing.  The rest of the meal was delish.  Service is a bit on the slow side, even for sushi, but it's a 3 woman operation, so I cut 'em some slack.  

All in all, one of the most enjoyable sushi meals I've had in a long time.
author: Mari B.

description:
This tiny little sushi bar is AWESOME!   

There are only about four tables and a small bar.  My girlfriend and I were staying in the hotel across the street and happened upon this place. 

they start off by serving brown rice green tea - a free salad.  both very good. 

I had the  Lizzie roll and the Rainbow roll- the salmon was really really fresh.  You get eight pieces per roll and it was all scrumptious.  

my girlfriend had the Hana roll, the freshest eel  she has ever had .

It is also very cool that there is a female sushi chef. You don't see that very often.
author: Zev X.

description: I'm always amazed at how small some restaurants in the city are.  Akiko's has 4 tables and a small bar.  It's pretty tiny.  The food was pretty good.  I got the miso soup, california roll, chicken teriyaki combo.  The soup and teriyaki were both fine.  The sushi tasted really great, but fell apart when I tried to pick it up.  I'd definitely come back here again because the food tastes good and the prices are great for the area.
author: Lizzy G.

description: Just finished lunch...good food spot and fun atmosphere east to interact with waiter/chef
author: Niles F.

description: Like all the other reviews here, this place is TINY! If you can get over the cramped feeling, the prices are actually really cheap here.  Too bad the service is incredibly slow...which I thought was surprising seeing as how there was barely anyone inside.  I regret trying this place out since the food and sushi weren't that good and took way too long to make.
author: Eugene H.

description:
I found the food to be so affordable for how delicious it is. If I were basing the review only on the food and value, it would be close to 5 stars. However, I arrived with all four tables packed (I sat at the sushi bar), and 3 of the orders had yet to be filled. Anything "hot" -- i.e., miso soup, udon, etc. -- will come quickly. All the cold sushi is made by a lone chef who is not lightening fast. My miso soup and edamame came very quickly, but I had to wait 30 mins for my one maki roll (spicy scallop -- and it was delicious!).  

My advice to you would be to look in first and see how busy it is, and how many of the four table already have their food. Then you can judge just how long your wait may be. If the place were only half-full, or more people had already had their orders filled, I probably would have had a much nicer experience.
author: Wendy J.

description:
I just got back from Akiko's after reading the reviews here. I must say, thanks for nothing Yelpers. I'm not sure what you guys had but this was dreadful. I eat sushi once a week and only once had an experience this bad.

The woman working there appear to be suffering from clinical depression. Barely a smile until I paid. The spider roll was the best thing I had and I wouldn't feed it to an enemy. The San Francisco roll was fishy and the avocado in all rolls was mushy and slimy. The other roll, double diamond or something, listed snow crab on the menu but had Krab stick in it. The house Sake, was to die for, seriously, it made me want to die. The stools? the stools? They're very high and the counter is low, I had trouble reaching my food.

If this was an off day I'll never know, I'm never going back.
author: Big P.

description:
it's cute but wtf? 

- no ice cube w/ drink? wtf
- took 1432 hours to bring out the last piece of the meal. wtf
- I swear they serve canned tuna in a roll. wtf
- forgot to bring out extra ginger. wtf 
- mediocre dragon roll? wtf

+ the space was cute +
+ yummy miso +
author: Nushaw G.

description: I'm always cravin for some Akiko's. Maybe it's the yummy furikake that they roll my sushi into. The ladies there are so cute, they know me by face now. This place is tiny, so you might miss it if you were walking by. I heart philly rolls!
author: Beth W.

description: "Lunch Special- Chicken Teriyaki - $8.50" was what the sign out front read. In the mood for Japanese food I went in. Small nice little place. Soooo the Teriyaki Chicken was marked down from it's original price of $8.95.....wow what a deal. I can't vouch for the sushi, but the Chicken Teriyaki was bad. The chicken had the texture that it had previously been frozen and cooked before it had properly thawed out. The teriyaki sauce was pretty bland as well. To top it all of it was served on top of a bed of vegetables (mushrooms, snap peas, and broccoli). I took a few bites paid my bill and left. What a disappointment. The hot tea and rice was fine, but its pretty hard to fuck up hot tea and rice....
author: Kevin K.

description: This place is very difficult to rate in stars.  The yellowtail speical roll (spicy yellowtail inside with avocado and cuc, yellowtail on top as well) gets 5 stars! The service was excellent too; it's a small place so they see when you are ready and are very friendly.  The negative is the space as well though. It's a very small place and lacks ambience (color, theme, music, cool decorations). Seats 12 or so.  This is cozy if you want a quiet lunch for yourself or eat alone and don't like to be seen eating alone. The sashimi combo was fresh and delicious too, so I would come back.  This is more of a quick bite place rather than a go-out-of-way kind of place. Great for what it is: decent sushi in a non-crowded spot with great service.
author: Aristocles P.

description: I am no sushi connoisseur, but I thought that the sushi at Akiko's was just okay.  I ordered hamachi and unagi nigri and spicy tuna maki.  The hamachi was fishier than I like,  the unagi pieces were on the less generous side.  The spicy tuna maki was good except that they were garnished with tobiko.  I think the sushi chef at Akiko's uses tobiko too liberally as they were also sprinkled on and inside the rolls that my friend had ordered.  Unfortunately, neither of us are huge fans of tobiko, so we spent some time and effort scraping off the eggs.  For what it's worth, I heard the waitstaff speaking to the sushi chef in Mandarin, so this either means that the chef is not Japanese, or he is just linguistically inclined.  Akiko's IS a cute sushi bar, though - I especially appreciated the painting of the octupus and the various usages of bamboo reeds in the space.
author: Grace W.

description:
my favorite, favorite, favorite sushi place!

it's a little hole-in-the-wall joint, but that is the great thing about this place, it's quite cozy.

the ladies who run the place are awesome, they are always cheerful and make you want to smile. the rolls are creative and delicious (try the lizzy roll if u haven't already) and pretty inexpensive too!
author: Thuy-Tu T.

description: After a string of bad sushi experiences, I was relieved to know that there still was some good sushi out there!  The place is tiny, so call ahead if you want take-out.
author: Kyla B.

description: overall service! better than so many other sushi resturant specially in the area. yes, it is a quite small resturant, but the food and the nice waitress really make it a 4 star place!!
author: Sawthatyet W.

description:
So I was back in San Francisco again (last time was last year in Feb 08; there's a reason for the timeline) and was looking for a good sushi place. Now, last year, the receptionist at the Sir Francis Drake suggested "Sushi Boat" off of Mason and Post. I didn't like it. Let's just say that (maybe I'll run over there and put a review in soon). So this year, I come back and ask someone else, they too suggested the Sushi Boat again. Forget it. I decided to jump on Yelp and found Akiko's Sushi off of Mason. Thanks other reviewers on Yelp.com. Thank you so much.

This place was great. Sure it was really small (it only had like what, like 5 tables and 5 seats at the sushi bar?), but hey, that added to the intimacy and it makes you feel that you're not forgotten in a big restaurant atmosphere. Whatever though about the size. The food here is great! I got the Phildelphia Roll Special (I think that's what it was...it wasn't the regular Philly Roll...) and the eel tasted amazing! I also ordered the Kamikaze Roll (which also had eel) and that was effin' fantastic! I do understand though, that everybody has their own personal preference on sushi, some are connoiseurs of the roll and some just simply get California Rolls and call themselves a sushi lover. I really have no more credibility than the next person aside from going to quite a few sushi places here and there. Regardless, personally, I think it's a great little place. I highly recommend it if you're in the area. It's a great way to start out your night cuz' then Cantina's right around the corner and they make excellent drinks. But that's for another review.
author: Anthony T.

description:
Have been spending lots of my time lately in the city and always in search of great sushi!  Happen to just step into Akiko's Sushi Bar one evening last week.  The fish here is great, some of the best i have found yet.  The roll menu is a bit short but out of the short list, there are none of the usual.  My favorites thus far are one with lemon pieces on top and another with minced sauteed garlic, I believe.

Will definitely be taking some of our sushi loving friends back there!  Very small location so not too large of groups and on the weekends, I was told they can have quite a line outside.  And do not confuse this place with the other Akiko's.  The best one is on Mason!
author: Mike Z.

description: Oh my gosh, what a cute little place..it probably literally holds only 10 people!  Amanda is right, the ladies who work there are really awesome.  Just tell them what you like and let them make you something special.  Our sushi was fresh and delicious, and we struck up a nice conversation at the little sushi bar with a great guy just in from Seattle on a business trip.  A good experience all around!
author: Sue U.

description: Very quaint, family-owned sushi joint. Good quality sushi, a little slow but the price is moderate for the area. I would and will definitely go back.
author: Hanan H.

description: The spicy tuna roll is amazing.  It's spicy as in "flavorful" not so much as in "hot"(which i also enjoy).  The San Francisco Maki I didn't enjoy as much, the shreds of crab on top freaked me out for some reason.   I love that for such a tiny place, on a Friday night, it wasn't crowded at all.  And the icing on the cake is that they bring you a plate of fruit out with the check to cleanse the palate!  and they give you different kinds each time, last time I had watermelon, last night it was oranges!  A thoroughly enjoyable sushi experience, one star off for the weird shredded crab.
author: Caleb D.

description: The food here is quite tasty, although I'm often freaked out by the staff; I prefer to get take out.  As someone else has said, the staff generally is quite dour.
author: Danielle G.

description:
Cheap and yummy!

Sushi pieces are pretty cheap (tuna was $3.75 for 2 pieces).  The roll I had (RCR - salmon, eel, avocado) was DELICIOUS and filling for $9.50.

Tiny tiny place.  And some sort of surfer dude as a waiter (I've never had a non-Japanese person serve me sushi).  But the food was quickly served and fresh!
author: Daryl K.

description: Cool little place for pretty good sushi.  Swamp roll and Lizzy roll are musthaves and the Sashimi salads are really great too.  Pretty small place so great for just 2 (as long as you have no scandalous things to say).
author: Dana C.

description:
this is my favorite little sushi place in the city. yes, it's tiny, but the fish is always super fresh and the women that work here are so friendly. 

i always get the sake nigiri with sliced lemon which is an amazing explosion of flavor and can make my mouth water just thinking about it. The miso soup is good, and so is the complimentary little dish of cabbage salad. They end the meal with a plate of fruit, usually oranges or watermelon which is a light and sweet way to end what has always been a perfect meal.
author: Erica H.

description: This is some delicious raw fish! They use fancy specks of fishy goodness that makes the rolls that much more divine! Friendly service and a nice 'hole in the wall' in the midst of Union Sq. Yay
author: Colleen B.

description: Oh, I love this place SO MUCH! The rolls are ALWAYS fresh, the room is cozy, the waitress makes you feel warm and welcomed every time you walk in through their door, the prices are below any of the sushi places on Union Square. The team works so efficiently, you don't even notice the gap between the time you've ordered and the sushi being brought to you. I have never felt more comfortable and taken care of in a right and respectful way, than in this place. Good job, keep it up, guys! P.S. Thank you for the spicy salmon roll last time!
author: Kate W.

description: Intereting church design for a little sushi joint. Close by if you work downtown, and the food is pretty good, reasonably priced, and fast.
author: Peter S.

description: This place is not authentic. If you're thinking about going here, keep walking and go to Ryoko's.
author: lisa m.

description: Tiny place, but cute and yummy.  I have to admit, though, the all stars go because I saw Sean Penn here several years ago :-)
author: Anya B.

description: Wow, this place is tiny!  The food was great though.  We had the sumo roll,  lizzy roll, spicy tuna roll and maguro.  All of the rolls were good, a little too much rice, but not tons too much.  the spicy tuna roll was great though!  Nice choices of rolls, overall a great experience close to Tourist Central.  Would def go back
author: Shane B.

description:
NOMOMOMOMOMOMOMOM

I was seriously ill but determined to have sushi while in town. This place hit the spot. And I didn't throw up afterwards.

I sat at the bar in this cute tiny place. Friendly service with affordable and delicious sushi.

The San Francisco maki was awesome, and it looked beautiful as well.


NOMOMOMOMOMOMOMOM
author: Jackson H.

description: Hole in the wall but excellent!  3 of us for dinner, each got a combo that included cabbage salad, miso soup, and sushi and/or sashimi.  $40 total.  Great service on top of everything.
author: Anne D.

description:
One star because I'll never go back and I regret going this time.

Tiny little place - no way to take a seat without first sticking your butt in some other diner's face.  Awkward.

Ate alone, took a little table against the wall.  Only had one chair - against the wall was a built-in bench.  Which was about 4 inches lower than the table....sat there first, and the table was tight against the top of my legs - would have had to bend over double to eat.  So I had to take the chair on the other side of the table, and eat while staring at the wall, while other diners occaisionally stuck their butt in my face.  Nice.

I ordered a tuna roll and a california roll.  No fancy stuff here, just your basic three-ingredient sushi.  Not a busy night.  Took 51 minutes for my food to arrive.  51 MINUTES!!!!!!!   While staring at the wall!!!!   I brought a book to read while I ate, and I finished it 30 minutes in.  They only brought my food when I stood up to walk out.  For christ's sake, I don't get 51 minutes to myself in a frickin' WEEK.....I can't invest that much time waiting for food that takes less than 5 minutes to eat.

And in all that time?  No refill on the coke.  Waitress never came back, wouldn't come if waved, nothing.  Had to eat my sushi dry, when it did finally come.  Yum.  And the waitress was CREEPY.  No noise - she didn't speak, she just mouthed words at you.  She wouldn't make eye contact, and drifted slowly across the room.  No noise when she walked, and when she poured water?  If it made more noise than she was happy with, she'd stop pouring for a second.  Dribble....dribble....drib...dribble....  For god's sake woman, hurry the fuck up!

I've lived in China for about a month, Japan for a few weeks, and several other Asian countries for at least a little while.  I'm familiar with the "quiet grace" or whatever that you sometimes get....but I've also done a couple years as a jail guard and seen a lot of battered women, and I'll bet you $100 this is the second category.  She just looked scared the entire time.  

Maybe that's why she doesn't bring anyone their food...she's back there trying to get her nerve up.
author: Barry H.

description:
i came out of my way on yelp to see what others thought of this place bc my experience was HORRIBLE.
i was starving and my bf and i came here. SOOOO DISSAPOINTED-- after one bite of my spicy tuna rolll i was grossed out and disappointed (ive had sushi all over and this gave sushi a HORRIBLE name).
the tuna was watery, NO taste and the salmon roll we ordered was GROSSSSS.
man i'm so disapointed i was hoping it would be good. DONT COME HERE
author: Ava A.

description: a little treasure(and i mean little) located near my school building on Sutter.Delicious sushi .Fresh fish.Attentive and friendly service. totally reasonable prices
author: Lauren V.

description: Cute, cute, and MORE CUTE! The female sushi chef is so cool. I can't complain about the service, which was friendly and prompt. I'm glad I came during an off-hour because the place is so small and I admit, I do get a little claustrophobic in tight places.
author: Nathalie L.

description: Small hole in the wall space that packs a huge amount of flavor! This is my favorite place for sushi. They have this amazing seasoning that they put on their sushi rolls. Every meal is served with your own pot of green tea and salad. The salad is delish! Don't go during lunch hour though due to the small space and one cook you may be waiting a long while for your food.
author: Meks R.

description: For a hole in the wall place they make really good sushi. I stopped last night after my Club One workout  and got two unagi nigiri, Unai, and a spicy crab roll to go. Once I got home oh boy! I hope that wasn't my hunger talking but it was really good and tasty. Especially the spicy crab that I shared with my workout buddy.
author: Karim R.

description: Only four tables, so if you pass this place and see one serendipitously open, seize it. The sashimi is incredibly fresh, the house rolls are inventive and exquisite, and the service is friendly. Astonishingly inexpensive. This place is a hidden treasure.
author: Max S.

description:
Horrible!

I've had better sushi from Safeway.  On top of that, the place is not even Japanese (despite pretending to be). When I asked for recommendations in Japanese, all I got was a blank stare. I tried again at the sushi counter and got the same blank look. Turns out they're Korean. They apparently don't even know what miso is!

Having lived in Japan for 3 years, I'm no neophyte when it comes to sushi, and I have to say that this place is the worst I've ever had. Either we went on a particularly bad night (a Thurs), or the people who gave it more than one star have no idea what they're talking about.
author: Eric B.

description: This is the best sushi I have had in a while.  The place is small, however the staff are wonderful and all the food is fantastic. Defiantly would recommend!
author: James M.

description:
i love/hate akiko's.

i love that;
it's a tiny hole in the wall and off the beaten path from crazy tourists.
the ladies are so friendly and know my order by heart.
they do not hurry me out when i finish my food and read my book for another 20 minutes.
the fruit dessert.

i hate that;
my hot tea turns ice cold in 30 seconds. seriously, i pour it from the tea pot into the tea cup and in 30 seconds it is cold.
their serving technique of the mismo soup (you think 'how odd', but watch next time they hand it to you)

i take the good with the bad and will keep going back.
author: Maureen P.

description: Great place to eat on your own because you are almost foolish to try going with any company.  Really good sushi, really good prices, and  really on nobody's radar since it is in a Union Square/Nob Hill/Tenderloin limbo, so if you're embarassed to eat solo, there's little chance you'll run into anyone you know passing by (unless they work out at Club One across the street).
author: Chris B.

description:
simply scrumptious. simply delightful. simply hidden.

If you've never been to akiko's, you should. I've heard a lot about it but never been until recently and I'm an instant fan! the sushi is fresh, and exciting. yes, exciting. not a typical way to describe sushi but appropriate. try something new on their menu and you'll know what i mean.
author: nic t.

description:
sick of the usual bullshit prices in the FiDi, i decided to go for a walk, up a hill, down a hill, and just generally away from here. it was well worth it.

a hole-in-the-wall place that takes credit cards and isn't too far from civilization. who would've known?

i sat down and noticed that there are four tables in addition to the tiny bar [spread your arms out, and that's how big the bar is]. this place isn't for the masses, even if it wanted to be.

from the plates to the paint on the walls and the pretty generous portions, everything was incredibly authentic, except that the workers weren't japanese, but they definitely knew what they were doing. 

the tea and soup are good, the salad they serve is appropriately a japanese salad [i mean, come on, who serves an american salad with thousand island at a japanese meal? any sushi place that doesn't serve a salad the japanese way is retarded], service is quick, and the ingredients are good & fresh.

all within walking distance of your favorite kinda/sorta union square destinations as well, specifically ruby skye and the theater district. can't complain.
author: Charles C.

description: One of my old roommates had been raving about Akiko's Sushi, so we had some sushi there last night.  This place is a tremendous value.  It's truly a little hole in the wall located in the highly congested Union Square area.  There is little ambiance but for above average sushi and generous portions, it is a great place.  The chef's special consisted of a 7 piece sushi combo, a small cabbage salad, and miso soup for $8.50. I also got some salmon maki rolls for a few extra bucks.  They also served small pieces of watermelon with the check.  I spent about $12, well below the usual $15-$20   I usually shell out to be even semi-full.
author: Josh K.

description: This is my favorite sushi place of all time. I always thought that Akiko's would be pretty bad for groups, however on Saturday, 9 of us were seated together and it was great! My favorite thing there is the Nigiri Sake . . . actually, that's all I ever order, but it's consistently fabulous. The only thing I've had that I really dislike is their complementary house salad, but usually someone else will eat it. My girlfriend loves the Udon bowl and all of my friends who went with us on Saturday enjoyed the various rolls. If you want great, casual sushi, this is a great place for it.
author: Allison B.

description: I probably stop by Akiko's every two weeks or so not only because the food is good but because the ladies that work there are so friendly.  Akiko's is my favorite hole-in-the-wall eatery in San Francisco and I whole heartedly recommend having dinner or lunch there.  Since it is a one woman show the service is a little slow when there is a full house.  My favorite rolls include the San Francisco roll, spicy tuna roll, and Dragon roll.  The complimentary salad during the beginning of the meal is pretty darn good too!
author: Helen B.

description: Service can be extremely slow, but the food is pretty good and the mountainous dish (I forget what it's called now, but it comes with crispies!) is a favorite. I met up with a friend from NYC here and she enjoyed it, too.
author: Lily Ann B.

description: Made the mistake of ordering oyakodon here... well attempting to anyway, since the waitress didn't understand me. I'm not sure how you can run a Japanese restaurant and not know what oyakodon is, it's like running an American restaurant and not understanding mac and cheese. Anyway I ended up with the chicken donburi instead which was OK but not great. The tuna sushi was very good however, a nice cut of very fresh fish! The spicy scallop roll was tasty, but not well prepared and fell apart.
author: Will A.

description: Asked for omakase and it turned out to be one of the best meals I've had in a long time. This place is amazing. Great selection of fish and the chef is a true pro. Honestly one of the best sushi meals I have had in my life (and I've been to some really amazing spots in NYC and LA). Can't recommend it enough.
author: Ian H.

description: This is possibly my favorite sushi place in the city.  Always top quality fish, reasonable prices and friendly service.  Not much room inside but good things come in small spaces. ;)
author: Nick C.

description: Good price for good sushi except for the avacados they put in my spicy tuna roll..eh...   They give you free hot tea and oranges for dessert, which is quite generous for a restaurant in Union Square.  The only downfall is that the restaurant is SO small and it made me feel very claustrophobic.
author: Erica C.

description:
I found this place after scouring Yelp for a good sushi restaurant in the FiDi to take some clients to. All the others were rated in the 2-2.5 star range which is not something I am comfortable with. I have eaten here 4-5 times and have been happy with it.
Price is not an object as it is reimbursed by the company, if I were to go on my own dime it is a little pricey. 
The quality of the fish is consistently very good. I always order the salmon (sliced lemon in between pieces of fish) and yellowtail sashimi. They serve normal color ginger not that weird pink stuff. 
For those who like the rolls: the spicy tuna roll is great because they don't put a bunch of mayo in it. Mayo=sickening. The Volcano roll is a wonderful pile of fried crab over a spicy salmon roll; very rich.
The service is pretty good. I haven't gotten to know them because I only go about 1x per month and with clients so we are talking about stuff. I typically like to get to know my sushi chef but time has not allowed it. Oh well. They are always nice.
We always time our arrival either by 11:45 or after 1 so we can beat the crowds.
Oh yeah, the presentation is beautiful. Not the wham/bam/thank ya mam type joint. 
I am not a sushi snob so I can't advise on the properness of how they do things. I am a good quality food type person and they keep me very satisfied in that regard.
I will continue to go here until they give me a reason not to.
author: colleen b.

description: Nice atmosphere, and good fresh sushi!  Located in between Nob Hill and Financial District,  Akiko has a nice variety of sushi at a competitive price.  Dinner for three with Sake only ran about $60.  The service was OK but nothing exceptional.  Overall, I would recommend this as a good place to check out if you are in the area but I wouldn't recommend traveling across the city to try Akiko's out.
author: Scott S.

description: Very cute hole in the wall. The service is excellent and the sushi is fresh and delicious. The California rolls are good too!  Chicken or Beef Teriyaki is available for those non-sushi lovers as well.  Pretty inexpensive.
author: Claire S.

description: YUMMY!  We are Austinites that are visiting San Francisco.  The sushi place that was recommended to us was closed and we were hungry now.  I did a Yelp search for what was near our hotel and came up with this.  The place is teeny tiny and we were the only ones there (we went at 2pm).  I was a little nervous but the food was just awesome.  The fish was really fresh.  The salad, soup, nigiri, rolls, ebi, and chicken teryaki (yes, I ordered something cooked just in case) were all fabulous.  Highly recommended.  It's a little hole in the wall but awesome.
author: Mom to T.

description: This little hole in the wall is amazing! Always serves fresh fish that melts in your mouth. Great simple rolls and low prices. Love!
author: Nicole F.

description:
food: 3/5
service: 5/5
atmosphere: 4/5
would come back again, but not often

This is a nice, small, hole in the wall place that makes decent sushi. The lady who makes the sushi and one of the waitresses are from Taishan, china. Don't try speaking to them in english, it won't help much. The main waitress speaks english, though. For a moment there I felt I was in a chinatown restuarant because the two older taishanese ladies were all gossipy like the people in the dim sum restaurants, lol. I started talking to them and they were really chatty, kinda good/kinda awkward. You may have a different experience if you don't understand the dialect.
      The sushi was decent. But the price was good for the quality. And I went during happy hour for drinks. 
      I think what will keep me from comming back is the good service and nice atmosphere. I like the small room setting, and its clean too. Everyone was very nice. the only thing I didn't like was that the bathrooms are in the apartment building's basement next door.
author: Cecile S.

description:
I love smaller venues that focus on a specific genre of food. Do one thing and do it right! This little sushi bar delivered fresh fish in good portions. I had a few choice cuts of white tuna that stood out. Also, the spicy salmon skin hand rolls were very very good. 

The sushi chef was an older (japanese?) woman, and to be honest I underestimated her on first blush. My bad, she did a nice job of putting our meal together! 

I'll be going back and will update on the consistency.
author: Brian M.

description: Don't let the sidewalk entrance fool you! This place was fantastic! I was dining alone and sat at the bar. One of the sushi chefs was especially kind to me--even substituted the blue fin tuna special for the other tuna in my Tahoe Roll. I also had the chef's choice rainbow roll and it was crazy good. The house wine was quite good and the service was spot-on. My only negative comment is the price, but I also ordered the most expensive roll (rainbow).
author: Jillian H.

description: We were hanging out at the Irish Bank next door and wanted to grab some sushi so we went here.  I didn't expect much because I've never heard much about this sushi joint.  Turned out to be one of the freshest sushi.  The albacore and hamachi just melted on the first bite.  heaven.  Joe (think thats his name) the sushi chef was super friendly and hooked us up with some complimentary dishes as a cool chef always does.  Mixed in with some warm saki to start the buzz, we were very satisfied.  So yes go here and eat at the sushi bar, and be ready to spend some hard earned cash on some great food!
author: Nagoo N.

description: It was ok.  There is better sushi around.  The staff was nice. Not fast or anything. Maybe it improves after lunch time.
author: Heidi P.

description: Me and my best friend go here all the time. It's one of our special finds. It's also the best sushi place I've ever been to. I highly recommend this place if you're into cozy, hole-in-the-wall places. They always give you salad and fruit, which is in season, with your meal. Prices are awesome and so is the chef! By the way the sushi chef is a woman, which adds more points to this fantastic restaurant.
author: Remilla A.

description: Not a hygenic restuarant, not particularly fresh ingredients, not so tasty and not very good service. It feels much more Chinese than Japanese and that's because its owned and operated by Chinese.
author: Frank W.

description: good sushi.. nice little hole in the wall
author: Fady A.

description:
Yelp reviews initially inspired my friends and I to pay a visit to what was described as a charming, homey san francisco sushi delight. Unfortunately, yelp has failed me. I am sitting in the restaurant, if it can even be described as such, as I write this review on my blackberry.

The fact that I am able to write this while with two other friends should be indicative of the efficiency and service of the establishment. Among the three of us, we each ordered a dunburi and a sushi roll. Literally an hour later, we are still waiting for our rolls. Over the course of the past hour, I learned that restaurants can indeed be run by infants. There are three people that are currently working this 4 table restaurant. You would think that would make for a faster, more intimate setting right?  Come and see for yourself if you want to be neglected by the waiter and waste 2 hrs of your life.

Also in this past hour, I have witnessed two to-go customers wait an average of 40 min for a roll each.

In short, the food (actually just the rolls) is above average, but the service is a thousand times below par.
author: Steve T.

description: it never occurred to me to associate the word "burrito" with sushi, but after becoming over-stuffed on only two of akiko's delectable handrolls, no other word sufficed to describe these culinary delights.  this place freakin' rocks - unbelievably reasonable prices for very fresh fish and generous servings.  everything i've had there has been excellent, and i'd especially recommend giving the unagi & spicy salmon handroll a try.  also, the service is quite pleasant, and it's nice to see a female sushi chef behind the bar.
author: genevieve g.

description: i work around the corner from this place so it has become my regular sushi dinner place.  the ladies that work there are the sweetest and always make me feel welcome.  the prices are reasonable and the sushi pretty good.
author: amanda w.

description: The sushi was pretty good and the prices were too. However, the ambiance was awkward and disappointing. Nothing is wrong with a teeny tiny hole-in-the-wall joint, but the lack of music and suitable-sized tables - or any room for tables- (and the terribly loud group next to us) made us anxious to leave.
author: ashley k.

description: Just moved to the city and was searching for a good sushi place, it was very small (seats about 12) I ordered the terryaki chicken 4 pc. california roll special which I liked because I usually like my sushi with eel/unagi sauce but they put some kind or seasoning on the rice where it tastes great without. I also ordered the smoked salmon (Sake Maki) which was alright but, a bit dry (my boyfriend liked it).My boyfriend ordered the spicy salmon roll (only 2 pc.) both of us weren't too fond of it, it was a strange roll and the salmon was very mushy(shredded?). Also there were 2 things flying around that looked like mosquitoes or something that scared us but, overall i think I like the place my food was good and they didn't charge me for the glass I broke. I really wish there was more of a selection of rolls though.
author: krissie t.

description: This is really a small restaurant. So, don't try to invite ten of your friends to this restaurant, because you all will be sitting on each other's lap. There's one sushi chef and she makes all of the sushi. If you are eating there, be sure to order other items on the menu. They also do take-aways which is nice. I order my food in advance then I walked over and paid for my food, but I had to wait for the lovely sushi chef to make my food; which was cool. The sushi bar is across street from my favorite gym, Club One on Mason. I want to give a shout to out the Club One staff, thanks for recommeding this cool sushi bar to me. The bar had a cool menu, the prices were reasonable, it won't break you. I order, the Kappa Maki, Avacado Maki, Caifornia Makki and the Spicy Tuna Makki. They were all good, but the Spicy Tuna wasn't spicy enough for me, I had to add more wasabi, to give it some heat. I will go back to try other items on the menu
author: Baseemah R.

description: one of the sushi places in FiDi.  once you're in for lunch, order right away.  they take a noticeably long time.  had the oyakodon and sushi combo with tonkatsu.  oyakodon is on the more liquidy side with much more onion than egg.  sushi straight forward.  tonkatsu done nicely.  overall a decent place to rotate among Mikaku (cheaper, izakaya board at dinner) and Muracci (curry joint)
author: Rob C.

description: A bare bones sushi experience. Very basic interior. Small room (4 tables). Friendly staff. Food was pretty good. Most of the sashimi was very good, but the tuna was slightly aged (not smelly or anything, just not in its prime). The salads are great and creative. Highly recommended. The prices are considerably lower than of the more fancy competition. Hence, if you are in for a quick dinner, this is a great place...
author: Mark S.

description: i love this place.  it is extremely small- only holds about 10 people at a time.  the sushi is great and reason,able and the environment is really cozy.  the best part is that it is a female sushi chef and an all female staff!  way to break those cultural barriers ladies.
author: charlene l.

description: I LOVE Akiko's.  I know its been said already, but the Lizzie Roll?  Off the hook.  Soo delicious.  Its just a salmon roll with slivers of lemon on top, which sounds incredibly simple, but it is just incredibly good.  Seriously, I've made so many of my friends come here just so I could stop by for this roll and some miso soup, its ridiculous.  I actually came here for my birthday with about 12 people, which you would think would pretty much fill up the entire restaurant, but they squeezed us in and left a table for 2 and the bar open... it was pretty crazy.  They do take reservations, but call the day of your reservation to reconfirm too - I called the day of and they had no idea 12 people were coming to dinner.  But hey, at least they do take reservations.  Don't expect the fastest service, because there's only one sushi chef here, but do expect good quality stuff.  Man, if I didn't have to drive so far to get it, i'd totally hit it up right now.  sushi monster want sushi...
author: Margie N.
